description: LOD, Israel  The Arabs and Jews of Lod, one of the most closely mixed cities in Israel, have been through many upheavals. But they had never before seen the kind of intercommunity violence that unfolded here over the past three days.

title: Candidates divided on defund the police issue as shooting and homicides rise in New York City.
description: The idea of defunding the police, which a year ago became a rallying cry after the murder of George Floyd, proved to be a contentious proposition during the debate, dividing the candidates along ideological lines, particularly as New York City reels from an uptick in crime.

title: Vaccinated Americans May Go Without Masks in Most Places, Federal Officials Say
description: Federal health officials on Thursday advised Americans who are fully vaccinated against the coronavirus that they could stop wearing masks or maintaining social distance in most settings, the clearest sign yet that the pandemic might be nearing an end in the United States.

title: Who Should Lead New York City?
description: Here are the mayoral candidates in their own words, so voters can make up their own minds.

title: A $1 Million Incentive to Get the Shot
description: Gov. Mike DeWine of Ohio announced five prizes for residents who had received at least one dose of a Covid-19 vaccine.

title: What Does the New Mask Guidance Really Mean?
description: More than a year after federal health officials told Americans to cover their faces when venturing out in public, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Thursday that fully vaccinated people could start taking off their masks indoors.

title: Delta will require that new employees be vaccinated.
description: Delta Air Lines will require new hires to be vaccinated against the coronavirus, but will exempt current employees from that mandate, making it one of the first major corporations to embrace such a requirement.

title: How Republicans Could Steal the 2024 Election
description: Erica Newland serves as counsel for Protect Democracy, a nonprofit organization founded in 2017 to fight democratic breakdown in America. Before Joe Bidens victory was officially confirmed in January, she researched some of the ways that Donald Trumps allies in Congress might sabotage the process. She came to a harrowing conclusion.

title: Colonial Pipeline Paid Roughly $5 Million in Ransom to Hackers
description: WASHINGTON  The operator of a critical fuel pipeline on the East Coast paid extortionists roughly 75 Bitcoin  or nearly $5 million  to recover its stolen data, according to people briefed on the transaction, clearing the way for gas to begin flowing again but complicating President Bidens efforts to deter future attacks.

title: We would hate to use the mute function on anyone: Virtual debate leads to some awkward moments.
description: At the start of tonights debate, Errol Louis, the lead moderator, asked the candidates about policing in New York City. As each spoke, the others listened quietly, waiting for their moment to speak.

title: Scott M. Stringer says he welcomes an investigation into sexual assault allegation.
description: Scott M. Stringer said he welcomed an investigation into a sexual assault allegation he is facing from a former campaign worker.

title: Andrew Yang was put on the defensive about his voting record and his role in Georgia Senate election.
description: Andrew Yang, who has been criticized multiple times during the campaign for being out of touch with New York City voters, found himself on the defensive once again during the debate, when Erroll Louis, the moderator, pressed him on the fact that he had not voted in several local elections.

title: Here is where the candidates stand on affordable housing.
description: The citys housing crisis has become a key issue in the mayors race  and not just because two candidates, Ray McGuire and Shaun Donovan, were ridiculed this week after estimating that the median price of a Brooklyn home was about $100,000. (Its actually $900,000).

title: Philadelphia Health Chief Resigns Over Cremation of Remains From MOVE Bombing
description: Philadelphias health commissioner has resigned under pressure after confiding to city officials that he had authorized the cremation and disposal of remains from at least one of the Black Philadelphians who were killed when the police dropped a bomb on a rowhouse where members of the communal, antigovernment group MOVE lived in 1985.

title: Ex-Aide to Congressman Claims He Was Fired for Voicing Virus Concerns
description: A former aide to Representative Doug Lamborn, Republican of Colorado, filed a lawsuit on Thursday claiming that he was fired after complaining about his bosss disregard for safety measures meant to protect congressional staff members from the coronavirus, which he said resulted in an outbreak in Mr. Lamborns office.

title: What to Know About the Yankees Coronavirus Outbreak
description: Gleyber Torres, the Yankees two-time All-Star shortstop, became the eighth person involved with the Yankees organization to test positive for the coronavirus this week, the team announced on Thursday. But what has caught the attention of many outside of the baseball world is that Torres, three coaches and four support staff members had all been fully vaccinated.

title: Corrections: May 14, 2021
description: An article on Thursday about Senator Shelley Moore Capito of West Virginia and her  possible infrastructure deal with the White House misstated the size of President Bidens plan. It is $2.3 trillion, not $2.3 billion.

title: Quotation of the Day: Fully Vaccinated Can Shed Masks, C.D.C. Says
description: We have all longed for this moment. If you are fully vaccinated, you can start doing the things that you had stopped doing because of the pandemic.

title: Leftovers From a Doughnut, Say
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  Yacob Yonas has a way of evoking a specific memory, of making a solitary solver laugh out loud and then stopping us dead with a seemingly light clue that leads to a weighty answer. He does all three in this puzzle, his eighth crossword for The New York Times.

title: New York Mayoral Candidates Debate Policing
description: Candidates were asked about their positions on police reform at a time when the city has experienced a rise in crime.

title: Here are five takeaways from the first Democratic debate for mayor of New York City.
description: The debate was spirited, at times fast-paced and occasionally awkward, with the eight candidates for the Democratic nomination for mayor of New York engaging with one another in a virtual format that left little room for the usual onstage theatrics.

title: Stringer Is Asked About Assault Allegation in Mayoral Debate
description: Scott M. Stringer, a candidate for mayor in New York, denied a sexual assault allegation made against him and said he would welcome an investigation.

title: Candidates Clash Over Future of New York in First Mayoral Debate
description: The two leading candidates in the New York City mayors race battled to protect their advantages in a hard-hitting Democratic debate on Thursday evening while their six rivals grasped for breakout moments, sought to redefine the stakes of the contest and put forth their own visions for the struggling city.

title: University of South Carolina President Resigns After Speech Blunders
description: Nearly a week ago, students graduating at the University of South Carolina heard their president, Robert Caslen, a retired Army lieutenant general, give a commencement speech about how they had prevailed during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Yangs Voting Record Is Discussed in Mayoral Debate
description: Andrew Yang was questioned during the New York City mayoral debate on Thursday about why he had not voted in several local elections.

title: Scorecard: Winners and Losers of New Yorks Mayoral Debate
description: Welcome to the Times Opinion scorecard for New York Citys first mayoral debate of 2021, which featured the eight leading Democratic candidates on Thursday night. A mix of Times writers and outside political experts assessed the contenders performances and rated them on a scale of one to 10: One means the candidate probably didnt belong on the virtual stage and certainly not in Gracie Mansion; 10 means he or she is ready to take over from the current mayor, Bill de Blasio, who cant run again because of the citys term-limits law.

title: The Bear Chased Us. Then We Chased the Bear.
description: The bear chased us. Then we chased the bear.

title: Shohei Ohtani Unleashed
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Seventy-two years after his death, Babe Ruth, again, is having a moment. So, too, are Ted Radcliffe, Harvey Haddix, Sudden Sam McDowell, Bullet Joe Rogan, Leon Day and many others.

title: Were Hungry: The Liberty Aim High in a Bounce-Back Season
description: Liberty Coach Walt Hopkins and his staff reviewed last seasons film looking for answers beyond the box scores and advanced analytics. Why was their defensive rating so low? Who was getting burned on screens? It was a trying year for a first-year head coach and his team, which ended with the second-worst winning percentage in W.N.B.A. history and a 2-20 record.

title: Masterpiece Theater: A Tale of Dueling Art Books for Kids
description: HOW TO BE AN ART REBELBy Ben StreetIllustrated by Jay Daniel Wright

title: The Racial Gap in U.S. Vaccinations Is Shrinking, but Work Remains
description: Known vaccination rates for Hispanic, Black, Native and Asian populations all now outpace vaccination for white people per capita. But because they have lagged for months, states still have significant ground to make up.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Israeli ground forces attacked the Gaza Strip early this morning in an escalation of the conflict that has so far killed 103 Palestinians and seven Israelis, according to the local authorities. Children have been among the casualties on both sides.

title: Australias Never-Ending Travel Ban
description: This week, it was reported that travel restrictions to and from Australia are likely to remain in place until mid-2022. For some, this wont matter much at all  many Australians are far more grateful for the safety of our isolation than worried about the inability to travel or have overseas visitors. For others, travel has been an integral way of life, and this news comes as a disappointment and inconvenience. And then there are the thousands and thousands of people who are cut off from loved ones in a way that feels earth-shattering.

title: Jimmy Fallon Is Psyched About Going Maskless
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous nights highlights that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Were all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: Word of the Day: rescind
Packing
Expert Picks: Who Will Win the Preakness?
description: Medina Spirit, who won the Kentucky Derby on May 1 to give the trainer Bob Baffert a record seventh victory in the race, was installed as the 9-5 morning-line favorite in Saturdays Preakness Stakes, despite nearly not running at all after it was disclosed that he had tested positive for betamethasone, a corticosteroid, after the Derby.

title: Hes a Dogecoin Millionaire. And Hes Not Selling.
description: Last February, when Glauber Contessoto decided to invest his life savings in Dogecoin, his friends had concerns.

title: Beneath Joe Bidens Folksy Demeanor, a Short Fuse and an Obsession With Details
description: WASHINGTON  The commander in chief was taking his time, as usual.

title: The Moon, Mars and Beyond: Chinas Ambitious Plans in Space
description: A week after its successful Mars landing, China said it had deployed a land rover on the planets surface, a feat that only the United States had accomplished before.

title: From Newsroom to Classroom: When Times Staff Members Double as Professors
description: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

description: Featured article: The Math That Explains the End of the Pandemic

description: In many ways, the trajectory of Lieke Martenss career has mirrored the growth of professional womens soccer in Europe.

description: To the Editor:

title: New in Paperback: Hamnet and All the Way to the Tigers
description: HAMNET: A Novel of the Plague, by Maggie OFarrell. (Vintage, 320 pp., $16.95.) At the center of this National Book Critics Circle Award winner  one of the Book Reviews 10 Best Books of 2020  is the question of why Shakespeare may have titled his most famous play for his son, who died at age 11. According to our reviewer, Geraldine Brooks, OFarrells novel is at once about the transfiguration of life into art and a master class in how the author herself does it.

title: The New York Times News Quiz, May 14, 2021
description: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

title: First a Third Wheel, Then a Couple
description: When asked what they believed brought them together in December 2017, Dr. Christine Gruessner and Przemyslaw Grabowski each offered an explanation that could be summed up in a single word: magnetism.

title: What Makes a Good Chinese Father? In a New Novel, Its Complicated.
description: MY GOOD SONBy Yang Huang

title: Emptying the Nest. Again.
description: When Kristine Mestazs son, Jeremy Cunningham, now 20, moved to Arizona for college, she was sad but supportive and grew accustomed to his absence. Then the pandemic happened and her nest was refilled: He returned home to Auburn, Calif., in March 2020 for spring break, but didnt leave, as his school, Arizona State University, went online.

title: Side by Side at Work, and Now in Life
description: Bria Schirripa can easily rattle off many of Michael Buccarellis admirable qualities.

title: His Song Got Her Attention
description: Mary Alexandra Kougeas Crowley perked up her ears when Justin Warren Douds sang Im just a bachelor. Im looking for a partner the winter of 2014 at a karaoke league competition at a Washington bar. Neither, though, was looking for a partner at the time.

title: Visualizing Robert Frosts Seminal Poem
What Is the Best Way to Get Teenagers Vaccinated?
description: On Monday, the Food and Drug Administration authorized the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine for children ages 12 to 15 in the United States, a crucial step in the nations recovery from the pandemic and a boon to millions of American families eager for a return to normalcy.

title: Bach Invented. Now a Pianist Is Trying to Match Him.
description: Of course Bach is a million times greater than me, the pianist Dan Tepfer said recently. I can still have a conversation with him.

title: The Proposal Was Real, the Medical Emergency Not So Much
description: If the April 16 ruse Michael T. Matthews concocted to convince his girlfriend, Amy Marshall, that she would have to deliver a baby on a median at 108th and Broadway demonstrated anything, it was that he knows her well.

title: Status Games, Polyamory and the Merits of Meritocracy
description: Agnes Callard is an ethical philosopher who dissects, in dazzlingly precise detail, familiar human experiences that we think we understand. Whether her topic is expressing anger, fighting with others, jockeying for status, giving advice or navigating jealousy, Callard provokes us to rethink the emotions and habits that govern how we live. She also happens to be one of my favorite columnists.

title: How Dr. Wafaa El-Sadr, Epidemiology Professor, Spends Her Sundays
description: Even though she is a lauded epidemiologist, Covids severity took Dr. Wafaa El-Sadr, a professor at Columbia University, by surprise. People in my world always felt there was a possibility of a pandemic by a new virus, she said, but the magnitude and speed at which it happened, and the profound impact on the world, was beyond what I imagined.

title: The Spike in Shootings During the Pandemic May Outlast the Virus
description: A man in Queens was fatally shot in the stomach outside a celebration thrown for his birthday. Another in the Bronx who stopped to check on a strangers well-being was struck in the head and torso and died. A 17-year-old was killed near his school in Brooklyn after end-of-day dismissal.

title: United by a Deep Connection to Brooklyn
description: Michelle Lorenzutti and David Alperin began dating in 2019, but in some ways their love story started much earlier, when their great-grandparents arrived in Brooklyn in the first half of the 20th Century. That history turned out to be key to the connection the couple developed decades later.

title: Richie Shazam Is a Multi-Hyphenated Renaissance Woman
description: Name: Richie Shazam

title: A Late-Pandemic Commute, Feeding Hate on YouTube and the Mariachis Unsilenced by Covid: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote the story.

title: Will We All Want to Be Wearing Halston Soon?
description: It was bound to happen. After the viral trendsetting of the 60s shifts in The Queens Gambit and the 80s puff sleeves of The Crown, it was only a matter of time before Netflix embraced fashion as the Next Great Brand Extension. And what better test than a show based entirely on the life and times of a great designer?

title: Guantnamo Detainee Agrees to Drop Call for C.I.A. Testimony
description: WASHINGTON  A detainee at Guantnamo Bay has agreed to a deal intended to lead to his release in the next few years in return for giving up the right to question the C.I.A. in court about its torture program, United States government officials said.

title: He Said (I Do), She Said (I Do)
description: When Nick Cugini received a Facebook friend request from Stacey Chen, he was intrigued, and a little amused.

title: What You Didnt Know About Barkley L. Hendricks
description: Barkley L. Hendricks portrayed Black people who exude attitude. In the Black community, you stand out because you declare your own sense of identity beyond your environment, said his longtime friend Richard J. Watson, artist-in-residence at the African American Museum in Philadelphia. When you see yourself shown as a standout  and not because you havent eaten in three days and youre a symbol of poverty  that gives you respectability.

title: A Friend of Tom or Cant Be Bothered: One Mans Rules at Bank of America
description: Early on in the pandemic, Bank of America found an innovative way to gauge the success of the banks work-from-home experiment: a spreadsheet, distributed to team managers daily, that pitted the productivity of people working from home against those who were still showing up at the office.

title: Immerse Yourself in Indigenous Culture
description: Cultural attractions like theaters and museums took a hit during the pandemic. But for those interested in heritage tourism or Indigenous culture in the United States, immersing yourself can be done safely and simply, outside.

title: Lies on Social Media Inflame Israeli-Palestinian Conflict
description: In a 28-second video, which was posted to Twitter this week by a spokesman for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, Palestinian militants in the Gaza Strip appeared to launch rocket attacks at Israelis from densely populated civilian areas.

title: Spy Agencies Seek New Afghan Allies as U.S. Withdraws
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Western spy agencies are evaluating and courting regional leaders outside the Afghan government who might be able to provide intelligence about terrorist threats long after U.S. forces withdraw, according to current and former American, European and Afghan officials.

title: Forget Backstage Passes or V.I.P. Bracelets. Vaccination Cards Are the New Ticket.
description: At Fort Bragg, soldiers who have gotten their coronavirus vaccines can go to a gym where no masks are required, with no limits on who can work out together. Treadmills are on and zipping, unlike those in 13 other gyms where unvaccinated troops cant use the machines, everyone must mask up and restrictions remain on how many can bench-press at one time.

title: Meet the Nun Who Wants You to Remember You Will Die
description: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

title: The Busy East End
description: Many second home owners in the Hamptons have spent most of the pandemic out east.

title: The Hamptons Boom Continues
description: The high-flying Hamptons real estate market continues to soar.

title: Uruguay has the worlds highest death toll per capita.
description: BUENOS AIRES  For most of the past year, Uruguay was held up as an example for keeping the coronavirus from spreading widely as neighboring countries grappled with soaring death tolls.

title: The new U.S. guidance on masks is a ticket to freedom, but comes with questions.
description: New federal guidance from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which cleared the way for people in the United States who are fully vaccinated against the coronavirus to drop mask-wearing in most situations, still came with plenty of caveats and confusion for Americans on Friday. It sent state and local officials, as well as private companies, scrambling to decide whether and when to update their own rules.

title: First Shots for a Younger Set of New Yorkers
description: [Want to get New York Today by email? Heres the sign-up.]

title: Miss Universe Myanmar Arrives in Florida With a Message for the Junta
description: As a girl, Ma Thuzar Wint Lwin would watch the Miss Universe pageant and wish that she could be the one onstage representing her country, Myanmar. She entered her first two contests last year, nervous and excited about what to expect. But she ultimately walked away crowned Miss Universe Myanmar, and this week is competing at the global pageant in Florida.

title: Singapore announces new restrictions after vaccinated airport workers become infected.
description: SINGAPORE  Singapore said on Friday that it would ban dining in restaurants and gatherings of more than two people to try to stem a rise in coronavirus cases, becoming the latest Asian nation to reintroduce restrictions after keeping the illness mostly in check for months.

title: A Conversation With a Dogecoin Millionaire
description: This episode contains strong language.

title: The Nautical and Agricultural North Fork
description: Buyers looking for open spaces during the pandemic flocked to the North Fork.

title: The North Fork Has Its Own Market Moment
description: Home prices have been climbing on the North Fork for years now, but the market went into overdrive when the pandemic hit, and the impact could be long-term.

title: Losers, Lovers, Strivers: The 60-Second Novelist Is Ready to Listen
description: The day after the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announced that fully vaccinated people could safely go outside without masks, I headed to the street with my 1941 Remington typewriter, folding chair and a little sign that read, Your Life Story in About a Minute.

title: Vaccine Hesitancy in Rural Tennessee
description: Hi everyone, happy Friday. Our team has been busy this week, covering the news from Silicon Valley to Jerusalem. On Fridays, we take some time to plan our week ahead. So wed love to know: What would you like to hear an episode about in the coming days? Let us know here  we always love to hear what is on your mind.

title: A C.D.C. About-Face
description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is finally catching up to the science.

title: What to Know About Spiral and the Saw Franchise
description: You dont have to know a thing about the horror movie Saw or its spawn before watching the latest movie in the franchise, Spiral: From the Book of Saw, opening in theaters on Friday.

title: What Would George Washington Look Like Today? A Pandemic Creation Draws Attention.
description: What would George Washington look like if he were a modern-day politician? That question occurred to George Aquilla Hardy, a musician, 14 months into the pandemic. There he was at 23, stuck in his childhood bedroom in Dorset, England, instead of playing music festivals.

title: Protesters in Jordan march to the Israeli border in support of Palestinians.
description: AMMAN, Jordan  Thousands of protesters in Jordan, Israels eastern neighbor, marched toward the border on Friday morning, chanting slogans in solidarity with the Palestinians and waving Palestinian flags as Jordanian riot police surrounded them.

title: New Mask Rules Are Tricky for Business
description: Want this newsletter delivered directly to your inbox? Sign up here.

title: Going on a Scavenger Hunt to Finish Your Kitchen Renovation
description: I recently showed up at the Habitat for Humanity ReStore in Randolph, N.J., about 10 minutes after it opened, and already the warehouse was full of customers looking for secondhand light fixtures, door knobs, bedroom sets, sofas and windows.

title: Police Received Worried Calls Days Before North Carolina Killings
description: For two years, Isaac Barnes became increasingly paranoid.

title: The variant first detected in India is forcing the U.K. to speed up delivery of second doses of vaccine.
description: LONDON  Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain said on Friday that vaccination protocols would be changed to swiftly deliver second doses to people over 50 to combat the spread of a coronavirus variant first detected in India, a warning sign for countries that are easing restrictions even though their own vaccination campaigns are incomplete.

title: The 1,000-Year Secret That Made Betta Fish Beautiful
description: For centuries, humans have been captivated by the beauty of the betta. Their slender bodies and oversized fins, which hang like bolts of silk, come in a variety of vibrant colors seldom seen in nature.

title: In the Virgin Islands, Fungi Tells a Story
description: At Petite Pump Room, a waterfront restaurant in Charlotte Amalie on the island of St. Thomas, lunchtime usually finds locals and visitors filling the tables and bar, taking in the islands hills and watching seaplanes take off and land in the harbor from nearby St. Croix.

title: Consumer Spending Flattens After March Jump, a Sign of a Rocky Recovery
description: Retail sales were flat last month after a buoyant March, the Commerce Department said on Friday, as Americans continued spending their latest round of government stimulus checks.

title: How to Navigate a Hot Housing Market
description: The home-buying market this spring is not for the faint of heart.

title: Giorgio Armanis Perfect Wire-Rimmed Glasses
description: GIORGIO ARMANI, NOW 86 and still leading the Milan-based fashion house he founded in 1975, is a master of expansion and evolution. Since gaining international attention with Richard Geres wardrobe in Paul Schraders noirish 1980 film American Gigolo, the designer liberated a generation of men from boxy black-and-navy Brooks Brothers conformity with his draped linen jackets and suits in shades of dove and cappuccino. Informed by the traditions of Italian tailoring, Japanese aesthetics and Art Deco, his empire now encompasses everything from furnishings to fragrance, but he has never wavered in his dedication to monochromatic modernity.

title: Faith-Based Investing Makes Up Ground in Gains and Convenience
description: The intersection of faith and money can be complicated.

title: In Southampton, a Cottage on the Harbor for Sale
description: The Hamptons getaway is on the market for $4.65 million

title: The Writer Kati Marton Is Selling Her Cottage in Southampton
description: For the author Kati Marton, the Hamptons have been a welcome haven for many years, especially Southampton.

title: Uncovering the History of Americas First Koreatown
description: Good morning.

title: They Met Online. Through Wikipedia, That Is.
description: When Courtney Elizabeth Thurston and Matthew Paul Del Buono first met in person, they didnt know each other as Courtney Thurston and Matthew Del Buono; they knew each other as IShadowed and Shirik. Those were the aliases that Ms. Thurston and Mr. Del Buono used as contributors to Wikipedia.

title: The Beatific Re-emergence of Beverly Glenn-Copeland
description: For decades, Beverly Glenn-Copeland made music heard by a precious few. In the early 1970s, he trained in classical music performance, and then released a couple of folk albums. In the 1980s, he made new age keyboard music. For the most part, he worked in childrens television.

title: Prince Harry Shares Pain and Suffering of Growing Up in Royal Family
description: LONDON  Prince Harry compared his life in the British monarchy as a mix between The Truman Show and being in a zoo in a wide-ranging interview released on Thursday night, one of his strongest public rebuttals yet of the inner workings of the royal family.

title: British Fraud Unit Is Investigating Gupta and Greensill
description: Britains financial crime unit is investigating suspected fraud and money laundering involving the businesses of Sanjeev Gupta, whose global metals empire ballooned in recent years with the aid of billions of dollars in financing from the failed  firm Greensill Capital.

title: Review: A Choreographer Looks Back on His Pandemic Year
description: The choreographer Stephen Petronio is easing into veteran status, having formed his company in 1984 and created a steady stream of dances since. But when he was first figuring things out, Trisha Brown gave him  he was the first male dancer in her company  what every young dance artist needs. She rented him a space in the basement of her loft. I had 5,000 square feet for a $100 a month for many years, he said during a virtual Joyce Theater discussion in April, and that launched my career.

title: The Conductor Who Whipped American Orchestras Into Shape
description: For those who grew to musical maturity with the concert life of the United States in the 1930s and 1940s, his name may still have an aura, Halina Rodzinski wrote in her memoirs, almost two decades after the death of her spouse, the Polish conductor Artur Rodzinski.

title: Sarah Colt on Why 2021 Is the Right Time for a Film About Billy Graham
description: Tenacious and tireless, Billy Graham was blessed with what more than one observer called animal magnetism. When he died at age 99 in 2018, he was estimated to have preached in person to 210 million people.

title: No Smile, No Trash Talk: Behind Tim Duncans Quiet Excellence
description: Tim Duncan stoically spent 19 fundamentally sound seasons allowing his play to speak for him.

title: Looking for Bipartisan Accord? Just Ask About Big Business.
description: Republicans in Washington and around the country have soured on big business, joining Democrats in expressing concern that corporations wield too much influence. The shift has left corporate America with fewer allies in a tumultuous period for American society and the global economy.

title: A Kevin Spacey Accuser Tried to Sue Anonymously. A Judge Said No.
description: The man said he was 14 years old when he was sexually assaulted by the actor Kevin Spacey in the early 1980s. Last year he filed a lawsuit against Mr. Spacey in which he sought to maintain anonymity, identifying himself in court papers only as C.D.

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Good morning. I wrote about the Texas restaurateur Jennifer Hwa Dobbertin for The Times this week, and of course theres a recipe: the red-cooked short ribs (above) served at Best Quality Daughter, the restaurant Dobbertin runs with the chef Quealy Watson in San Antonio. Its a really delicious feed, to eat as they do at the restaurant, with lettuce wraps and rice.

title: The Lost Days of Ral Jimnez
description: Ral Jimnez remembers arriving in London with his Wolverhampton Wanderers teammates. He remembers walking onto the field at the Emirates Stadium an hour or so before that November game against Arsenal, briefly taking in his surroundings and heading back inside to get changed. He would, as usual, be leading the Wolves attack.

title: Target Stops Selling Pokmon Cards, Citing Safety Concerns in Stores
description: The intense demand for Pokmon trading cards, which steadily rose in recent years then rocketed up even more during the pandemic, has caused Target to temporarily suspend sales of the cards, citing a threat to the safety of customers and workers.

title: At-Home Care for the Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: Tom Wilson Is Hockeys Chief Villain. Or Is He?
description: Washington Capitals forward Tom Wilson, according to some of his peers, is a menace. A bully. A punk. A goon. He is reckless, vicious, dirty, and bad for hockey. He might have fit in 30 years ago, but his conduct  illegal checks and high hits, at the price of five suspensions in his career  has no place in todays safety-conscious N.H.L.

title: Elise Stefanik Elected as Liz Cheneys Replacement in G.O.P. Leadership
description: House Republicans announced on Friday that they elected Representative Elise Stefanik of New York to replace Representative Liz Cheney as the No. 3 House Republican during a party conference Friday.

title: The Best of Late Night This Week
description: The late-night hosts riffed on the Kentucky Derby winners failed drug test, Jeff Bezos superyacht, the G.O.P. ouster of Liz Cheney and the C.D.C.s new guidelines on masks.

title: Stream These 5 Action Films Now
description: For the action movie fans looking for new thrills to watch at home, there are a lot of car chases, explosions and sword and fist fights to sift through. Let me help you by providing some streaming highlights. This months picks include films from around the globe and tonally range from spell-bindingly fantastical to the surprisingly comical.

title: The Hoover Dam Made Life in the West Possible. Or So We Thought.
description: LAKE MEAD, Nev. Few things force you to confront hubris and genius at the same time as much as the magnificent harness on the Colorado River that created the largest reservoir in the United States.

title: Comfort Viewing: 3 Reasons I Love The Nanny
description: Since the arrival of all six seasons of The Nanny on HBO Max last month, there were a couple of weeks when it seemed as if everyone I knew or followed was watching. If, while stuck indoors, youve been a little too glued to social media, you may have seen the excited posts and whole accounts devoted to the glory of Fran Dreschers wit and fashion sense. Style writers have been effusive, calling the show iconic, a master class in sitcom fashion and wonderfully horny.

title: Your Car, Toaster, Even Washing Machine, Cant Work Without Them. And Theres a Global Shortage.
description: As the fallout from Covid wreaks havoc on supply chains, a major economic and geopolitical tug of war has broken out.

title: Our Fellow Evangelicals Need to Get Vaccinated
description: The pathway to ending the Covid-19 pandemic runs through the evangelical church. Tens of millions of evangelical Christians live in the United States, and almost half of white evangelicals surveyed have said they are reluctant to get vaccinated against Covid. For many outside the evangelical world, this resistance seems incomprehensible. But as lifelong evangelicals, we understand why this is happening, and we worry that our community is obstructing recovery from the pandemic.

title: On Parole, Staying Free Means Staying Clean and Sober
description: Joy Thompson was in her early 50s when she started using opioids.

title: If Youre Reading Stoicism for Life Hacks, Youre Missing the Point
description: Modern Stoicism has become an industry. And a mega-industry at that.

title: Were Not Ready for the Next Big Climate Disasters
description: The infrastructure bills taking shape in Congress will be the first test of the Biden administrations ability to legislate on climate change. Most eyes are on how greener infrastructure can cut emissions of warming gases.

title: Breathing Through the Rectum Saves Oxygen-Starved Mice and Pigs
description: Dr. Caleb Kelly, a gastroenterology fellow at Yale University, was recently asked to review a paper about mammals receiving lifesaving oxygen through their anuses. I laughed, to be honest, he said. I thought it was a joke.

title: On Spotify, an Arranged Marriage Between Music and Podcasts
description: Danyel Smith used to make a podcast in her kitchen. Smith, an author, journalist and former editor in chief of Vibe magazine, recorded it with her husband, Elliott Wilson, a fellow journalist and the founder of Rap Radar, between the sink and a bowl of fruit.

title: Shes a Texas Democrat, Weighing How to Defend Voting Rights
description: As Republicans in the Texas Legislature run roughshod over corporate opposition, public protests and Democratic objections to advance a voting restrictions bill to the brink of passage, State Representative Jessica Gonzlez, a two-term Democrat from near Dallas, has been at the forefront of the fight.

title: Nicki Minaj Reunites With Lil Wayne and Drake, and 13 More New Songs
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

title: Curtis Fuller, a Powerful Voice on Jazz Trombone, Dies at 88
description: Curtis Fuller, a trombonist and composer whose expansive sound and powerful sense of swing made him a driving force in postwar jazz, died on May 8 at a nursing home in Detroit. He was 88.

title: Eight people from the New York Yankees organization tested positive, despite having been vaccinated. Heres what to know.
description: Gleyber Torres, the Yankees two-time All-Star shortstop, became the eighth person involved with the Yankees organization to test positive for the coronavirus this week, the team announced on Thursday. But what has caught the attention of many outside of the baseball world is that Torres, three coaches and four support staff members had all been fully vaccinated.

title: A Deep Look at One Classroom
description: Susan Dominus, a staff writer at The New York Times Magazine, spent much of the school year with one sophomore class in Columbia, Mo. Today were breaking our usual weekly schedule to tell you about her phenomenal article chronicling the experience.

title: A.O.C. Had a Catchy Logo. Now Progressives Everywhere Are Copying It.
description: In her three years in the national spotlight, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez has become the undisputed face of unabashed progressivism. But there is another hidden-in-plain-sight legacy of her 2018 primary victory: Her campaign logo and poster have reshaped the visual branding of the left.

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Agnes Callard
description: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like todays episode with Agnes Callard. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

title: The 2021 N.H.L. Playoffs Are Underway
description: You hear a lot of superlatives about the N.H.L. playoffs. Does hockey have the most exciting playoffs? Is the Stanley Cup the hardest trophy to win in sports? Are its customs and traditions the most mythic and profound?

title: After 15 Months, a Milestone: The C.D.C.s New Guidance on Masks
description: To the Editor:

title: Just-Right Recipes
description: The sun is out. Ive made my annual switch to iced coffee. Im buying Lambrusco and making a spritz. Summer is nigh! After the year we all had, you will catch me indoors only when its time to sleep, shower or type on this laptop (and maybe not even then).

title: Avalanche Are Cup Favorites, but Even the Islanders Can Dream
description: The N.H.L. playoffs begin on Saturday the same way the 56-game regular season played out: the schedule featured entirely intradivisional play and the postseason will be no different through the first two rounds.

title: The Weekender
description: A onetime homeless chess champion has become a chess master, at only 10 years old. Also in this edition: the lure of H Mart, and the hidden cost of your vacation photos.

title: A Tahini Lemon Cranberry Bar Dreams of Whole Foods
description: Lupii bars were supposed to have a breakout year. Or, at the very least, be something people might have heard of.

title: Consumers may be expecting higher inflation, posing potential trouble for the Fed.
description: Americans are penciling in higher inflation not just over the next year but over the next five years, according to a survey measure that Federal Reserve officials have a history of watching closely. That could spell trouble for the central bank, which relies on low and stable inflation expectations as an enabler of its low-interest-rate plans.

title: Pervis Staples, Who Harmonized With the Staple Singers, Dies at 85
description: Pervis Staples, who sang harmony and also provided quieter forms of support during the rise to gospel stardom of his familys group, the Staple Singers, died on May 6 at his home in Dolton, Ill. He was 85.

title: Former Gaetz Confidant Agrees to Plead Guilty and Cooperate
description: A former confidant of Representative Matt Gaetz admitted in court papers on Friday to an array of federal crimes, including sex trafficking of a 17-year-old girl, and agreed to cooperate with the Justice Departments ongoing investigations.

title: Ohio Governor Announces Lottery to Get More Americans Vaccinated
description: Gov. Mike DeWine of Ohio announced on Wednesday that residents could win $1 million for having received at least one dose of the coronavirus vaccine in an effort to get more Americans vaccinated.

title: Elise Stefanik Is Playing a Dangerous Game With Her Career
description: The rapid rise of Representative Elise Stefanik of New York to the post of chief pro-Trump messenger in the ongoing battle for the soul of the G.O.P. has sparked a flurry of media reports about how a supposed onetime moderate Republican metamorphosed into a full-fledged fire-breathing far-right conservative.

title: Filling Your Summer Calendar? Slow Your Roll.
description: When Mayor Bill de Blasio announced New Yorks summer reopening, Daniel Roque-Coplin and his girlfriend saw a chance to rekindle their relationship after a year spent on the couch watching Netflix. But soon, the promise of a summer visiting bars, restaurants and museums they had frequented prepandemic felt more overwhelming than exciting.

title: Love Letter: The Benefits of Childhood Friends
description: We all remember our first childhood friend. The one you were always excited to see. The one who made every play date feel like an adventure. And most important, the one who accepted you completely, quirks and all.

title: Rash of Subway Attacks Raises Worries With 24-Hour Service Set to Return
description: In the span of 12 minutes early Friday, the police said, a group of men attacked commuters aboard a moving subway train, increasing concerns about public safety in New York Citys transit system just as 24-hour subway service is set to resume on Monday.

title: Destruction in Gaza After Israeli Bombing
description: Hundreds of Palestinians woke up to destruction on Friday morning after Israel bombed parts of the Gaza Strip.

title: Make Time to Mourn
description: After the death of a loved one, the grief of each survivor is often different  but the ritual of holding a funeral is shared.

title: Hearing Begins for Man Linked to Missing Tiger in Houston
description: A court hearing for Victor Hugo Cuevas began on Friday. Police said he was involved with the disappearance of a tiger that was last seen on Sunday wandering a Houston neighborhood.

title: Louis Menand on The Free World
description: Louis Menands new book, The Free World: Art and Thought in the Cold War, covers the interchange of arts and ideas between the United States and Europe in the decades after World War II. On this weeks podcast, Menand talks about the book, including why he chose to frame his telling from the end of the war until 1965.

title: America Is Failing Its Moral Test on Vaccines
description: The United States is well on its way to protecting Americans from the coronavirus. Its time to help the rest of the world. By marshaling this nations vast resources to produce and distribute enough vaccines to meet global demand, the United States would act in keeping with the nations best traditions and highest aspirations while advancing its geopolitical and economic interests. It is a moment of both obligation and opportunity.

title: How the United States Beat the Variants, for Now
description: On Dec. 29, a National Guardsman in Colorado became the first known case in the United States of a contagious new variant of the coronavirus.

title: Bernie Sanders: The U.S. Must Stop Being an Apologist for the Netanyahu Government
description: Israel has the right to defend itself.

title: Alex Rodriguez and Partner Reach Deal on Timberwolves and Lynx
description: The baseball star Alex Rodriguez and his business partner Marc Lore have reached terms on a deal to purchase the N.B.A.s Minnesota Timberwolves and the W.N.B.A.s Minnesota Lynx for $1.5 billion.

title: As Congress Dithers, States Step In to Set Rules for the Internet
description: WASHINGTON  News outlets in Florida may soon be able to sue Facebook and Twitter if the social media companies take down their content.

title: Chinas Mars Rover Mission Lands on the Red Planet
description: The United States now has company on Mars.

title: Gaza Rocket Finds a Rare Gap in Israeli Armor, and a Boy Is Killed
description: SDEROT, Israel  It was 1:30 p.m. on Friday in Sderot, and Ido Avigal, 5, was being laid to rest a few miles to the north. He had been killed in what officials termed a freak incident two days earlier when a rocket from Gaza made a direct hit on the building next door to his aunts apartment, where he was visiting with his mother and older sister.

title: Why Charles Koch Wins When Our Energy System Breaks Down
description: When the Colonial Pipeline shut down in 2016, it sent a grave warning about Americas fragile energy system. Once the gasoline stopped flowing, thanks to an accidental breach by a construction crew in Alabama, millions of people along the East Coast who relied on the nearly 60-year-old, 5,500-mile-long sometimes leaky pipe for their daily energy needs suddenly felt marooned. Backup supplies dropped. Prices spiked in some markets.

title: Maybe We Need Masks Indoors Just a Bit Longer
description: On Thursday, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention updated its guidance to say it did not believe that fully vaccinated people needed to wear masks or distance indoors or out, with a few exceptions, like when using public transportation.

title: Andre Hills Family Reaches $10 Million Settlement With City of Columbus
description: City officials in Columbus, Ohio, have agreed to pay a $10 million settlement to the family of Andre Hill, a Black man who was fatally shot by a police officer in a garage in December.

title: Biden meets with DACA recipients as his administration grapples with the border surge.
description: President Biden met on Friday with six so-called Dreamers  participants in the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program  to illustrate his reversal from the Trump administrations immigration policy and to push for a reform bill in Congress.

title: In Israels Rising Violence, Ripples From 1948
description: On the afternoon of July 11, 1948, regiments of the newly formed state of Israel advanced toward the village of Lydda. They would conduct an operation there that, by many accounts, became formative to their new state and to the conflict that has continued ever since, and that echoes in the violence raging this week in that very same town, now known as Lod.

title: Martin Bashir Leaves BBC Amid Inquiry Into His Interview With Princess Diana
description: The journalist Martin Bashir has left the British Broadcasting Corporation, as it prepares to publish the findings of an investigation into accusations that he used dishonest tactics to secure a major 1995 television interview with Diana, Princess of Wales.

title: Arab World Condemns Israeli Violence but Takes Little Action
description: BRUSSELS  The Arab world is unified in condemning Israeli airstrikes in Gaza and the way the Israeli police invaded Jerusalems Aqsa Mosque, one of Islams holiest sites. Governments have spoken out, protests have taken place, social media is aflame.

title: In Stefanik, G.O.P. Installs a Trump Convert Who Reflects the Partys Shift
description: WASHINGTON  As Representative Elise Stefanik of New York watched then-candidate Donald J. Trump take her party by storm and win the Republican presidential nomination in 2016, she was so skeptical of his inflammatory style and hard-right positions that she refused  even when pressed  to say his name.

title: M.L.B. and Players Union File Grievances Against Each Other
description: The Major League Baseball Players Association recently filed a grievance over the shortened 2020 season, as they had threatened to do since negotiations with the league soured last summer.

title: Biden revokes more of Trumps executive actions, including moves on immigration and monuments.
description: The Biden administration on Friday revoked a Trump-era restriction on migrants who enter the country without health coverage and rolled back six executive orders intended to stoke anger over street protests and attacks on Confederate monuments in 2020.

title: Out of the Void: Teenagers Eager for Vaccination
description: Ready for a return to pep rallies and proms, these youngsters were quick to roll up their sleeves.

title: DarkSide, Blamed for Gas Pipeline Attack, Says It Is Shutting Down
description: The criminal hacking group DarkSide, which the F.B.I. has blamed for carrying out a ransomware attack that crippled fuel delivery across the Southeastern United States this week, has announced that it is shutting down because of unspecified pressure from the United States.

title: Masks, Israel, Tim Duncan: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Heres the sign-up.)

title: How Do You Feel About the New Mask Guidelines?
description: Federal health officials said on Thursday that people who were at least two weeks past their final dose of a coronavirus vaccine could safely go most places, both indoors and outdoors, without a mask. Governors and mayors across much of the country have since announced plans to relax or end their mask mandates. The changing and differing guidelines across state lines have led to some people feeling confused or unsure what advice to follow.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: On Thursday, as you know if you read this newsletter, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention dropped a bombshell: Fully vaccinated Americans can stop wearing masks and maintaining social distance in most settings  both indoors and outdoors.

title: When the Bus No Longer Rolls Into Town
description: Given that Greyhound had already suspended operations for about a year because of the pandemic, its announcement on Thursday that it was permanently ending all of its remaining bus service in Canada was almost symbolic.

title: Pipeline Attack Yields Urgent Lessons About U.S. Cybersecurity
description: For years, government officials and industry executives have run elaborate simulations of a targeted cyberattack on the power grid or gas pipelines in the United States, imagining how the country would respond.

title: Northwestern Athletic Director Resigns Amid Backlash Over Harassment Case
description: Erika Carter breathed a small sigh of relief when she learned that Mike Polisky had resigned as the Northwestern University athletic director after about 10 days in the role.

title: Federal Mask Retreat Sets Off Confusing Scramble for States and Cities
description: SAN ANTONIO  Minnesotas statewide mask mandate is over. But in Minneapolis, the states largest city, face coverings are still required.

title: Chad Kalepa Baybayan, Seafarer Who Sailed Using the Stars, Dies at 64
description: Chad Kalepa Baybayan, a revered Hawaiian seafarer who was a torchbearer for the art of wayfinding, which ancestral Polynesian sailors used to navigate the Pacific Ocean by studying the stars, trade winds and flight patterns of birds, died on April 8 at a friends home in Seattle. He was 64.

title: A Breakaway Third Party of Ex-Republicans? Dont Count on It.
description: A house divided against itself cannot stand, Abraham Lincoln declared in 1858, just two years before he assumed the mantle of the recently formed Republican Party. It will become all one thing or all the other.

title: Why the C.D.C. Changed Its Advice on Masks
description: Advice from federal health officials that fully vaccinated people could drop their masks in most settings came as a surprise to Americans, from state officials to scientific experts. Even the White House got less than a days notice from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the press secretary, Jen Psaki, said at a news briefing on Friday.

title: Leslie Moonves Receives Nothing From CBS Exit Package
description: Leslie Moonves, who led CBS as chief executive for 15 years before he was ousted in 2018, will receive nothing from the $120 million the company had set aside in a potential severance package, according to a federal filing on Friday.

title: Israeli-Palestinian Strife Widens as Frantic Calls for Calm Go Unheeded
description: CAIRO  Violence between Israelis and Palestinians expanded in new directions on Friday, with deadly clashes convulsing the occupied West Bank and anti-Israeli protests erupting along Israels borders with two Arab neighbors.

title: A Press Corps Deceived, and the Gaza Invasion That Wasnt
description: The Israeli military abruptly announced after midnight on Friday that its ground forces had begun attacking in the Gaza Strip, saying it on Twitter, in text messages to journalists, and in on-the-record confirmations by an English-speaking army spokesman.

title: Democrats Move Closer to Setting Up Jan. 6 Commission, With or Without G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON  House Democrats pressed ahead on Friday with a bipartisan proposal to create an independent commission to investigate the Jan. 6 Capitol attack, after reaching agreement with a key Republican to drop his partys demand that it look at left-wing violence unrelated to the assault.

title: N.Y.C. Mayoral Candidates Keep Focus on Crime After a Feisty Debate
description: On the day after the leading Democratic candidates for mayor faced off in the first major debate of the election season, Andrew Yang attended a conference on the future of the waterfront. Scott M. Stringer went to a vacant lot in Brooklyn to talk about affordable housing. Maya Wiley toured a Puerto Rican cultural center on the Lower East Side. Eric Adams attended fund-raisers, and Raymond J. McGuire greeted business owners on Staten Island.

title: Read the document: Plea Deal for Joel Greenberg
description: The plea deal for Joel Greenberg, the onetime associate of Representative Matt Gaetz who had served as a tax collector in Seminole County, Fla., north of Orlando, until he was indicted in 2020.

title: What to Do This Weekend
description: Want to get the At Home newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.

title: Barbara Stone, Modeling Agent to American Beauties, Dies at 87
description: Barbara Stone, who as a top agent nurtured the careers of a host of high-profile models, including Cheryl Tiegs, Cybill Shepherd and a young Martha Stewart, died on April 26 at a hospital in Roslyn, N.Y., on Long Island. She was 87.

title: Video Footage of Death of Black Man in South Carolina Jail Stirs Outrage
description: The death of a Black man after police used pepper spray and Tasers on him in a South Carolina jail has stirred outrage as well as widespread calls for changes to the treatment of people in custody suffering from mental illness.

title: Tulsa Race Massacre Commission Ousts Oklahoma Governor
description: Gov. Kevin Stitt of Oklahoma has been ousted from a commission set up to commemorate the centennial of the 1921 Tulsa race massacre, just days after he signed legislation that commission members said would undermine their goal of teaching the states painful history of racial discrimination.

title: Locks You Pick?
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  This themeless grid from Sam Trabucco feels as if it has an unexpected twist on every row and column, like a house of mirrors. I felt like that, anyway  a lot of funny surprises and connections, including that particular variety of pun where once you get it you wonder why you didnt see it sooner, or how your mind ever led you astray.

title: Corrections: May 15, 2021
description: An article on March 29 about climate change and steel companies referred incompletely to the gases converted by bacteria into useful chemicals in pilot programs by ArcelorMittal. Both carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide are converted, not carbon dioxide alone.

title: Quotation of the Day: Pipeline Hack Reveals Seams in Nations Cybersecurity Armor
description: Its all fun and games when we are stealing each others money. When we are messing with a societys ability to operate, we cant tolerate it.

title: The Fall Guy
description: The jokes almost wrote themselves. Last summer, Juventus announced that it had installed Andrea Pirlo as coach of its under-23 team. It was a thoroughly sensible idea: the perfect place for a beloved former player to cut his teeth in a new phase of his career, the ideal spot for him to take his first job in management.

title: Rombauer Wins the Preakness, Surging as Medina Spirit Fades to Third
description: BALTIMORE  Medina Spirit was running against more than the nine rivals on the track on Saturday. He was taking on an ex-president who had called him a junkie, late-night comics and a public skeptical of his natural talent after he won the Kentucky Derby two weeks ago but failed a drug test afterward.

title: Taiwan hits a daily case record.
description: Taiwan, which has had remarkable success in containing the coronavirus, raised restrictions for its main city to their highest level since the start of the pandemic on Saturday, after reporting a daily record of 180 new locally transmitted infections.

title: As Biden reaches out, Netanyahu vows attacks until Israels security is ensured.
description: The violence in Gaza entered a seventh consecutive day on Sunday, hours after President Biden spoke to the Israeli and Palestinian leaders and protests erupted anew in the occupied West Bank.

title: The Pandemic Has Split in Two
description: Zero deaths in some cities. Thousands in others. The pandemics fault lines continue to widen as vaccines flow toward rich countries.

title: Cicada Quiz: 17 Years Since Brood X and Bennifer. Remember When?
description: How much do you recall about 2004, the last time Brood X cicadas were mating and Ben Affleck and Jennifer Lopez were dating? Test your cultural memory here.

title: Kristen Radtke Considers Another American Epidemic: Loneliness
description: I started writing about loneliness by accident. It seems too simple to say I wrote about loneliness because I was often lonely, although I was. It was 2016, during an election cycle that left many of us feeling wrenched from reality, and suddenly I was seeing loneliness everywhere. Id walk down the street or step onto the subway during my morning commute and find that I couldnt stop watching people who were physically alone: someone eating a sloppy gyro on the curb while staring blankly into space, an exhausted nurse still in her scrubs nodding off on the bus, the bodega cashier scrolling absently through his phone before a backdrop of condoms and Fritos pinned to the wall. There was nothing verifiably lonely about any of these people, and the fact that I identified loneliness in them said a lot more about me than it did them. I wanted to see their loneliness because I was feeling it myself.

title: Daniel Patrick Moynihan Was Often Right. Joe Klein on Why It Still Matters.
description: The central conservative truth is that it is culture, not politics, that determines the success of a society, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York said during a lecture at Harvard in 1986. The central liberal truth is that politics can change a culture and save it from itself. Moynihan, an apostle of complexity, lived at the intersection of those two truths, a place where he was free to become one of the most creative American thinkers of the late 20th century. He sensed, and then came to know, that the social problems of what was being called postindustrial society would be different from those that came before. He identified these problems, sometimes controversially. In so doing, he predicted the dislocations of the 21st century with uncanny accuracy. He did it with elegance and wit and  this may be a surprise  transcendent humility. His spot-on sense of what truly mattered deserves to be revisited now, if were to grope our way past the mess weve become as a society.

title: The Assorted Teachings of Dogecoin
description: In 2013, two friends who met in a chat room created Dogecoin as a joke. Named after a meme of an expressive dog, it was meant to mock the self-serious cryptocurrencies of the time, many of which never took off. The joke did, though, and it spawned a community of enthusiasts who kept it alive for years  at a negligible price.

title: The G.O.P.s Big Cancellation
description: Mr. Potato Head is under siege.

title: Cuomo Accusers Are Subpoenaed as State Inquiry Enters a Critical Phase
description: ALBANY, N.Y.  Four women who have accused Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of sexual harassment have received subpoenas to testify under oath, the latest indication that the state attorney generals investigation into Mr. Cuomos behavior has entered a critical phase.

title: What TikTok Stars Owe The Ellen DeGeneres Show
description: In May 2010, well before the TikTok era, a 12-year-old from Oklahoma named Greyson Chance was summoned to The Ellen DeGeneres Show. A couple of weeks earlier, Greyson had found early viral fame after he posted his middle school talent show performance of Lady Gagas Paparazzi on YouTube. When Greyson came on the show, where he sat in a plush chair directly across from the daytime star and discussed his Gaga cover, the YouTube video had a million page views.

title: Syrias Surprising Solar Boom: Sunlight Powers the Night in Rebel Idlib
description: HARANABUSH, Syria  When the Syrian government attacked their village, Radwan al-Shimalis family hastily threw clothes, blankets and mattresses into their truck and sped off to begin new lives as refugees, leaving behind their house, farmland and television.

title: Secret Sharers: The Hidden Ties Between Private Spies and Journalists
description: Some journalists are happy to knock on the doors of strangers. I was never one of them, but Christopher Steele, the ex-British spy behind the infamous Trump dossier, left me no choice.

title: Tensions Among Democrats Grow Over Israel as the Left Defends Palestinians
description: In 1988, when James Zogby, the founder of the Arab American Institute, pushed Democrats to include a mention of Palestinian sovereignty in their platform, party leaders responded with a clear warning, he recalled: If the P-word is even in the platform, all hell will break loose. Eager to stave off an angry confrontation at the convention, the issue was shelved without a vote.

title: The Mogul in Search of a Kinder, Gentler Capitalism
description: A self-made multimillionaire who married into a revered European banking dynasty, Lynn Forester de Rothschild now spends her time calling for higher taxes on the wealthy, stricter regulation of big business and a wholesale reordering of the capitalist system that has delivered her such privilege.

title: Paulina Porizkova, Full-Frontal Emotion
description: When the writer and model Paulina Porizkova was asked by Aaron Sorkin to join him at the Oscars for what would be their second real date, she hesitated.

title: 723 Epidemiologists on When and How the U.S. Can Fully Return to Normal
description: Covid-19 cases are decreasing in the United States, and masks are no longer required everywhere, but the pandemic is not over  and wont be until younger children can also be vaccinated, epidemiologists said in a new survey by The New York Times.

title: How a Genetic Trait in Black People Can Give the Police Cover
description: When they carried the body of a 32-year-old Black man named Lamont Perry out of the woods in Wadesboro, N.C., there were no protests over his sudden death in police custody.

title: New York Is Dead. Long Live New York.
description: Its a ghost town, former President Donald J. Trump said of New York City last fall during a presidential debate. Its dying, everyones leaving New York.

title: Wild Horses Adopted Under a Federal Program Are Going to Slaughter
description: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

title: An annual day of Palestinian grievance comes amid the upheaval.
description: The convulsions in Israel and the Palestinian territories were injected with an additional source of angry emotion on Saturday as the Palestinian diaspora and its supporters commemorated Nakba Day, denoting the 1948 displacement of hundreds of thousands of Palestinians amid Israels declaration of independence.

title: An Israeli airstrike killed at least 10 members of a family in a Gaza refugee camp.
description: An Israeli airstrike that hit a house in a Gaza refugee camp killed at least 10 Palestinians from the same extended family overnight, eight of them children, according to witnesses. A 5-month-old infant was pulled from the rubble alive.

title: When Students Shared Their Struggles, They Helped Me With My Own
description: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

title: Your Questions About Vaccines at Work, Answered
description: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you dont already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.

title: In some U.S. counties, nearly all people over 65 are vaccinated.
description: More than 70 percent of Americans who are 65 or older are fully vaccinated, and 84 percent have received at least one dose, a much higher proportion than for younger Americans, according to federal data. The numbers have surpassed President Bidens goal of at least partly vaccinating 70 percent of the nations adults by July 4.

title: Kids Will Be Kids, but Their Parents Should Know Better
description: Q: I rent a ground-floor condo with a small patio in New Jersey. A family with two very young children recently moved into an adjacent building in the same complex. I often find the kids playing on my patio and looking into my apartment through a sliding door. There is no fence surrounding my patio, but its obvious that this is part of my private space. If their mother and I see each other outside, she shoos her boys away, but they keep coming back. Any suggestions for how to get them to play somewhere else, like the common lawn behind their building?

title: Shootings in New York spiked during the pandemic, and may outlast the virus.
description: As of the second weekend in May, New York City had recorded 505 shooting victims, the most through that point of any year in the last decade.

title: N.Y.C. Pride Will Take Steps to Keep Police Out of Parade and Events
description: New York Citys annual Pride celebration, which began 51 years ago as a defiant commemoration of an anti-police uprising and has evolved into a city-sanctioned equality jamboree, will take steps to reduce the presence of law enforcement at its events.

title: Violence Shakes Trumps Boast of New Middle East
description: WASHINGTON  It was, President Donald J. Trump proclaimed in September, the dawn of a new Middle East.

title: Bob Koester, Revered Figure in Jazz and Blues, Dies at 88
description: Bob Koester, who founded the influential Chicago blues and jazz label Delmark Records and was also the proprietor of an equally influential record store where players and fans mingled as they sought out new and vintage sounds, died on Wednesday at a care center in Evanston, Ill., near his home in Chicago. He was 88.

title: Medina Spirit and Horse Racings Deadly Drug Scandals
description: On May 1, Medina Spirit, a horse trained by Bob Baffert, one of the stars of thoroughbred racing, somewhat unexpectedly won the Kentucky Derby. About a week later, it emerged that the horse had tested positive for an anti-inflammatory pain-masking drug, throwing his victory into question. Mr. Baffert has been suspended by Churchill Downs, and the horse will most likely lose his win if a second sample confirms the first finding.

title: Bake Something!
description: The weekend has arrived. What are you baking? How about Genevieve Kos one-bowl carrot cake (above), with its slightly burnished and caramelized cream cheese topping? Or J. Kenji Lpez-Alts updated take on the Jim Laheys renowned no-knead bread? Perhaps the latest from Dorie Greenspan would entice, a casual gteau Basque that is equal parts crumbly, tender and chewy. If youd rather eat something savory, look no further than our most popular recipe of the week: chile-roasted chicken with honey, lemon and feta from Melissa Clark.

title: Hacked Pipeline Is Now Delivering Millions of Gallons an Hour, Owner Says
description: HOUSTON  The Colonial Pipeline, which delivers nearly half the transportation fuel to the Southeast and New York area, resumed full operations on Saturday, eight days after it was shut down by a ransomware attack.

title: Bias Is a Big Problem. But So Is Noise.
description: The word bias commonly appears in conversations about mistaken judgments and unfortunate decisions. We use it when there is discrimination, for instance against women or in favor of Ivy League graduates. But the meaning of the word is broader: A bias is any predictable error that inclines your judgment in a particular direction. For instance, we speak of bias when forecasts of sales are consistently optimistic or investment decisions overly cautious.

title: Education Poses an Existential Threat to Extremism
description: Lying in her hospital bed in Kabul, Afghanistan, having survived an extremist groups bombing that killed more than 80 students at her school, a 17-year-old named Arifa was as determined as she was frightened.

title: Young Americans, How Has George Floyds Death Influenced Your Life?
description: Darnella Frazier was just 17 when she recorded a video that shook the world. Her cellphone video, uploaded to Facebook, captured Derek Chauvin kneeling on George Floyds neck and upended the Minneapolis Police Departments official narrative of the encounter, ultimately contributing to a guilty verdict.

title: Israel Strikes Gaza Tower Housing A.P. and Other News Outlets
description: An Israeli airstrike destroyed a prominent building in Gaza City on Saturday that housed media outlets, including The Associated Press and Al Jazeera. The Israel Defense Forces said it gave an advanced warning for civilians to evacuate.

title: After Years of Quiet, Israeli-Palestinian Conflict Exploded. Why Now?
description: JERUSALEM  Twenty-seven days before the first rocket was fired from Gaza this week, a squad of Israeli police officers entered the Aqsa Mosque in Jerusalem, brushed the Palestinian attendants aside and strode across its vast limestone courtyard. Then they cut the cables to the loudspeakers that broadcast prayers to the faithful from four medieval minarets.

title: Conflict Spirals Across Israel and the Palestinian Territories
description: JERUSALEM  Fighting between Israelis and Palestinians spiraled across several fronts on Saturday as Israel destroyed a high-rise building in Gaza housing the offices of two major international media outlets, thousands of Palestinians fled their homes, Hamas militants in Gaza fired more rocket barrages toward the Tel Aviv area, and protests broke out again in the occupied West Bank.

title: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
description: PUNS AND ANAGRAMS  Everyone who enjoys Thursday themes and Saturday puns in daily puzzles should be delving into Sunday variety puzzles, especially cryptic crosswords and puns and anagrams, or Pandas. This grid is a perfect example: Its by a reliably excellent constructor of daily puzzles, and its full of inventive wordplay draped on a structure of anagrams that helps us fill in the blanks on the really tough stuff.

title: Violence in an Israeli town carries bitter echoes of 1948 for Palestinians.
description: On the afternoon of July 11, 1948, Israeli regiments conducted an operation in the town of Lydda that became formative to their new state, and echoes in the violence raging this week in that same town, now known as Lod.

title: A Police Shooting in Hawaii Has South Africans Demanding Justice
description: JOHANNESBURG  A plane from Honolulu landed in Johannesburg earlier this month and offloaded a plastic-wrapped coffin carrying the body of Lindani Myeni, a South African rugby player, aspiring singer and father.

title: What Would It Take to Vaccinate the World Against Covid?
description: In delivering vaccines, pharmaceutical companies aided by monumental government investments have given humanity a miraculous shot at liberation from the worst pandemic in a century.

title: Eula Hall, One-Woman Relief Agency in Appalachia, Dies at 93
description: Eula Hall was a tireless health care activist  so tireless that she wasn't about to let an arsonist slow her down.

title: Greek Neo-Nazi With Seat in European Parliament Is Sent to Prison
description: ATHENS  A convicted Greek neo-Nazi and member of the European Parliament was extradited back to Greece on Saturday to serve a 13-year prison term for his part in running the criminal organization Golden Dawn, once Greeces third-largest political party.

title: Should We Really Embrace 90s Fashion?
description: As far as I am concerned, when Harry Styles wore a yellow plaid Gucci blazer and lavender feather boa to perform at the Grammys in apparent homage to Alicia Silverstones character in Clueless, it was final proof (if any were needed) that the 90s, that decade of grunge, slip dresses, knee socks, chokers, tracksuits and oversize blazers (well, hello, Balenciaga), were, as you say, back in fashion.

title: An Everest expedition abandons base camp after several climbers test positive for the coronavirus.
description: KATHMANDU, Nepal  A prominent mountaineering company abandoned its expedition to Mount Everest, dismantling its tents at base camp on Saturday after members of its team tested positive for the coronavirus.

title: Jail Time and Big Fines: G.O.P. Seeks Harsh Penalties for Poll Workers
description: AUSTIN, Texas  Anita Phillips has been an election judge in Texas for 17 years, responsible for managing a precinct in Waco, a city of roughly 135,000 people. But over the last four years, the civic duty she prized has become arduous. Harassment by partisan poll watchers has grown increasingly caustic, she has found, and helping voters is ever more treacherous amid a thicket of new rules.

title: A Fragile Ceasefire Lets Afghans Risk Travel for Eid
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  On Saturday, the final day of a three-day national cease-fire for Eid al-Fitr, the three-day Muslim celebration marking the end of fasting after the holy month of Ramadan, the killings in Afghanistan kept coming.

title: At 18, He Had Consensual Gay Sex. Montana Wants Him to Stay a Registered Offender.
description: In 1993, when he was 18, Randall Menges had consensual sex with two other teenage boys at a camp in Idaho.

title: Yitzhak Arad, Who Led Holocaust Study Center in Israel, Dies at 94
description: Yitzhak Arad, who as an orphaned teenage partisan fought the Germans and their collaborators during World War II, then went on to become an esteemed scholar of the Holocaust and the longtime chairman of the Yad Vashem remembrance and research center in Israel, died on May 6 in a hospital in Tel Aviv. He was 94.

title: These stores, restaurants and parks are relaxing their mask policies.
description: A growing list of retailers, restaurants and theme parks will allow fully vaccinated customers and workers to go mask-free, following new coronavirus safety guidance from the federal government on May 13 that said vaccinated people rarely transmit the virus.

title: Fans are back, but Preakness attendance is capped at 10,000.
description: The pandemic wreaked havoc on the Triple Crown schedule in 2020. The Belmont Stakes, normally the final leg of the Triple Crown, was held in New York in June, the Derby in September, and the Preakness, usually the second of the three races, came in October. None of them admitted spectators. This year, all have returned to their regular spots on the calendar.

title: Heres how to watch the Preakness.
description: Coverage of the 146th Preakness Stakes began on NBC Sports Network at 2 p.m. Eastern time and moves to NBC at 5 p.m. Coverage will also be streamed on NBC Sports Live. Post time for the mile and three-sixteenths race is 6:57 p.m.

title: Biden calls for protection of civilians and journalists in calls with Israel and Palestinian leaders.
description: President Biden urged the leaders of Israel and the Palestinians to avoid additional deaths of children and other civilians in the escalating conflict on separate calls on Saturday and also affirmed his commitment to a two-state solution to bring peace in Jerusalem and elsewhere across Israel and the occupied territories.

title: University of California Will No Longer Consider SAT and ACT Scores
description: The University of California will not take SAT and ACT scores into account in admissions or scholarship decisions for its system of 10 schools, which include some of the nations most sought-after campuses, in accordance with a settlement in a lawsuit brought by students.

title: We know Medina Spirit, but what about Bob Bafferts other horse?
description: The world knows about Medina Spirit by now: the gritty Derby victory, the failed drug test and a long wait to see if the colt would be disqualified. But what about Bafferts other horse in the Preakness?

title: Leigh Perkins, Who Built Orvis Into a Lifestyle Brand, Dies at 93
description: Leigh H. Perkins, who built Orvis from a modest mail-order fishing tackle shop in Manchester, Vt., into one of Americas largest and most distinctive sporting lifestyle brands, with stores all over the country, died on May 7 at his home in Monticello, Fla. He was 93.

title: Fall River Ex-Mayor, Who Impressed Voters With His Zeal, Is Convicted of Corruption
