title: Prosecutors Investigating Whether Ukrainians Meddled in 2020 Election
description: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn have been investigating whether several Ukrainian officials helped orchestrate a wide-ranging plan to meddle in the 2020 presidential campaign, including using Rudolph W. Giuliani to spread their misleading claims about President Biden and tilt the election in Donald J. Trumps favor, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

title: Fielders Choice? Cubs Turn a Simple Grounder Into a Wild Run.
description: Baseballs long history has allowed ample opportunity for wackiness. It is, after all, a sport in which the coaches wear the same outfits as the players, the action runs counterclockwise and stealing is not only legal, it is encouraged.

title: Dianne Morales Tries to Calm a Sudden Crisis in Her Campaign
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton hosted a mayoral forum in Harlem on Tuesday night in preparation for his expected endorsement in the Democratic mayoral primary. All the leading candidates were in attendance, save for one  Dianne Morales, who cited a family emergency.

title: Coast Guard Search Fails to Locate 10 Cuban Migrants Lost at Sea
description: KEY WEST, Fla.  A second day of searching an area the size of Hawaii failed to turn up any sign of 10 Cuban migrants lost at sea after the boat they were traveling in sank off the Florida Keys, Coast Guard officials said on Friday.

title: U.S. Is Said to Have Unexamined Intelligence to Pore Over on Virus Origins
description: WASHINGTON  President Bidens call for a 90-day sprint to understand the origins of the coronavirus pandemic came after intelligence officials told the White House they had a raft of still-unexamined evidence that required additional computer analysis that might shed light on the mystery, according to senior administration officials.

title: San Jose Gunman Detested Workplace Long Before Rampage, Police Say
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  The first reports of gunfire at the Santa Clara Valley Transportation Authority light rail yard near downtown San Jose, Calif., came in at 6:34 a.m. on Wednesday, about half an hour into a morning shift.

title: Activists Demand Justice for Ronald Greene
description: Civil rights advocates and family members of Ronald Greene, a Black man who died in police custody in 2019, gathered Thursday at the Louisiana State Capitol to call for the troopers involved to be held accountable.

title: DMX Wanted a New Beginning. Swizz Beatz Is Seeing It Through.
description: DMX was supposed to start working out soon.

title: Cats Sup
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  Even though I enjoyed it, this was a tough one for me.

title: U.N. Rights Council to Investigate Israeli-Palestinian Violence
description: The United Nations top human rights body voted on Thursday to open an inquiry into abuses and possible war crimes committed in Israel and the occupied Palestinian territories during recent hostilities.

title: Nike Says It Ended Deal With Neymar Amid Investigation of Sexual Abuse
description: Nike ended its sponsorship agreement with the Brazilian soccer superstar Neymar last year after he refused to participate in an investigation of an accusation that he had sexually assaulted a Nike employee, the company confirmed Thursday night.

title: Taiwan Prays for Rain and Scrambles to Save Water
description: TAICHUNG, Taiwan  Lin Wei-Yi once gave little thought to the water sluicing through her shower nozzle, kitchen faucet and garden hose.

title: Former Astronaut Pleads Guilty in Crash That Killed 2 Young Girls
description: A former NASA space shuttle commander, who had been indicted on murder and assault charges for his role in a 2016 car crash that killed two young sisters in Alabama, pleaded guilty to lesser charges on Thursday and was sentenced to four years in prison followed by 10 years of probation.

title: Jose Peraza Helps Powers Mets to Pair of Wins Over Rockies
description: Jose Peraza homered starting the third inning of the opener and followed with a tiebreaking single in the fourth inning of the second game, helping the Mets sweep a doubleheader from the Colorado Rockies, 1-0 and 4-2, Thursday.

title: She Put Her Unspent Love in a Cardboard Box
description: In the back of my closet is a small cardboard chest with brass handles and latches that has followed me to every new address; its the first thing I find a place for as the moving truck pulls away. An old sticker on the bottom says it was purchased at Ross for $26.99. The only remaining contents are three wrapped presents marked in my mothers tidy cursive: Engagement, Wedding and First Baby.

title: Bruce Brown Is the Nets Swiss Army Knife
description: Brad Simpson, who has been the boys basketball coach at Wakefield Memorial High School in a Boston suburb for decades, first met Nets guard Bruce Brown at an informal summer workout before Brown entered eighth grade.

title: Quotation of the Day: Buried With Their Dreams and Nightmares
description: When I think about the children who died, I also think about the ones who survive, those who were pulled out of the rubble and lost a limb, or those who will go to school and see their friend is missing.

title: Editors Note: May 28, 2021
description: An article on Tuesday about allegations of workplace misconduct by Michael Larson, a longtime money manager for Bill Gates, included an incorrect description of a letter reporting an encounter between Mr. Larson and the bicycle shop manager who accused him of harassment. (The letter was sent by the womans lawyer to the Gateses).

title: Russia Appears to Carry Out Hack Through System Used by U.S. Aid Agency
description: WASHINGTON  A newly disclosed effort by Russian intelligence to hijack the email system of a United States government agency prompted leading Democrats on Friday to urge stronger action against Moscow for accelerating cyberattacks ahead of President Bidens summit next month with President Vladimir V. Putin.

title: From Protester to Prisoner: How Hong Kong Is Stifling Dissent
description: HONG KONG  Ten pro-democracy activists were sentenced in Hong Kong on Friday to prison terms ranging from 14 months to 18 months over a 2019 protest, the latest in a series of tough punishments that have put much of the Chinese territorys opposition camp behind bars, with many more awaiting trial.

title: Behind the Jim Crow Curtain
description: The city of Tulsa, Okla., unleashed hell on earth 100 years ago this month when it deputized part of the mob that looted and burned the prosperous African-American community of Greenwood. When the carnage subsided, perhaps as many as 300 Tulsans lay dead. Thirty-five square blocks of homes, churches and schools  along with a storied business district known as Black Wall Street  had been systematically torched and reduced to ash.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn are investigating whether several Ukrainian officials helped orchestrate a wide-ranging plan to meddle in the 2020 presidential campaign, including the possible use of Rudolph Giuliani to spread disinformation about Joe Biden and tilt the election in Donald Trumps favor, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

title: Canadian Lawmaker Is Exposed on Camera for a Second Time
description: OTTAWA  For the second time in just over a month, a member of Canadas Parliament has apologized for exposing himself during a virtual legislative session.

title: A Summer of the Thirst-Trap Short Shorts?
description: Its short-shorts summer, said Milo Ventimiglia, the This is Us actor who created a social media stir this April when he was photographed leaving a Los Angeles gym in teeny shorts that barely covered his muscular quads.

title: Word of the Day: obtrusive
description: Note: This is our final Word of the Day for the 2020-21 school year. The feature will start again in September.

title: Stephen Colbert Parodies Brian Kemps Version of the National Anthem
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous nights highlights that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: Phones and Fingers
description: What do you think this image is saying? Can you relate to it personally?

title: How a Cozy Neighborhood Restaurant Became a Celebrity Hide-Out
description: The scenic coasts of Northern Tuscany and Southern California are separated by approximately 6,000 miles; one runs along the Tyrrhenian Sea and the other, the Pacific Ocean.

title: A Sexual Abuse Lawsuit Splits the Gucci Family
description: For the last few months, scenes from Lake Como in Italy, where Ridley Scott is filming The House of Gucci, the movie about the murder-for-hire of Maurizio Gucci by his wife, have trended on social media. Viewers have cooed over the clothes and the stars, Adam Driver and Lady Gaga, while the family itself has lodged protests against what a Gucci scion Patrizia Gucci said was stealing the identity of a family to make a profit, to increase the income of the Hollywood system.

title: As Yangs New York Ties Are Questioned, He Cites Anti-Asian Bias
description: Andrew Yang, a son of Taiwanese immigrants and a leading candidate for mayor of New York City, took on issues of race and identity in extraordinarily personal terms on the campaign trail this week, seeking to reframe some criticisms of his candidacy as questions of his Americanness.

title: A New Zealand Fugitive Wanted to Turn Himself In. So He Hired a Helicopter.
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand  For many, it would be a welcome getaway: a weeks retreat in a log cabin deep in the New Zealand wilderness, followed by a scenic helicopter ride, a platter of oysters and a bottle of Champagne.

title: Where Wind and Solar Power Need to Grow for America to Meet Its Goals
description: A broad shift toward renewable energy could transform landscapes and coastlines all over the United States.

title: Lesson of the Day: TikTok, the Fastest Way on Earth to Become a Food Star
description: Featured Article: TikTok, the Fastest Way on Earth to Become a Food Star by Taylor Lorenz

title: The Eerie Familiarity of a Melbourne Lockdown
description: Its all so eerily familiar. The gray weather and afternoon sunsets. The anxious wait for the days numbers. The obsessive checking of exposure sites. The rumors of restrictions, followed by the reality of lockdown. The kids home from school. Birthday parties canceled, holidays postponed. The dreary, fearful, resigned uncertainty of it all.

title: A Forgotten Genocide: What Germany Did in Namibia, and What Its Saying Now
description: It has been called the first genocide of the 20th century, the forgotten genocide and the genocide that was the precursor of the Holocaust. Tens of thousands of Africans were killed between 1904 and 1908 by German soldiers in what is now Namibia, a vast, arid country northwest of South Africa.

title: New in Paperback: Love in the Blitz and Sunny Days
description: LOVE IN THE BLITZ: The Long-Lost Letters of a Brilliant Young Woman to Her Beloved on the Front, by Eileen Alexander. (Harper, 496 pp., $17.99.) Imagine how Jane Austen might have witnessed the Blitz, and you have a sense of this wonderful book, our reviewer, Thomas E. Ricks, raved about these recently discovered letters from a future translator of Georges Simenons detective novels to her lover in the R.A.F.

title: What Contributed to American Culture After World War II? And Other Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Airline Rebound Accelerates
description: After a miserable year, vaccinations and reopenings could lead to what airlines hope will be a summer flying frenzy.

title: The New York Times News Quiz, May 28, 2021
description: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

title: What Are You Grateful For?
description: Note: This is the last Student Opinion prompt for the 2020-21 school year. Our regular features will resume in September.

title: Two Notes a Day While the Doctors Away
description: Deborah Rachel Reich got a preview of Dr. Matthew Michael Levitskys hectic schedule in June 2019 when she asked if their first date was still on after they met on Hinge.

title: Was the Constitutional Right to Bear Arms Designed to Protect Slavery?
description: THE SECOND Race and Guns in a Fatally Unequal America By Carol Anderson

title: The Jewish History of Israel Is Over 3,000 Years Old. Thats Why Its Complicated.
description: My first visit to Israel was when I was 12 years old. The group was led by my father, a rabbi from Philadelphia. We had been invited to participate in an archaeological dig near the city of Beit Shean, in the countrys north, near the Jordan River Valley. Soon after we arrived, one of my friends happened upon a pottery shard, really an ostracon, a fragment with writing on it. The archaeologist on site said something to him in Hebrew. My father translated: He said you are the first person to hold that in over 2,000 years.

title: Waiting for That Defining Moment
description: Jaeyeon Janice Park and Dr. Joseph Jisoo Hong began dating shortly after meeting on the dating app Hinge in December 2019.

title: A Spiritual Meeting in the Sand and a Wedding There, Too
description: On the morning of April 24, Emily Arnold and Youssef Ait-Khouya walked over the dunes at Coral Pink Sand Dunes State Park outside Kanab, Utah, chose a spot to get married and began accessorizing it. They laid down Moroccan rugs and pillows, set up a portable table and decorated it with vases of flowers, a tea set and Moroccan lanterns. The surrounding dunes were continually changing shape because of the near-constant wind. A sign inside the park reads: When you left your car in the parking lot, you left stability behind.

title: The Case for Paying All Teachers Six Figures
description: During the Covid-19 pandemic, debates over school closures and student safety grew in an understandable way. But this back and forth left no oxygen for robust conversation about lagging salaries for K-12 educators  an issue that was finally getting the attention it deserved before Covid hit. But now that each week brings more vaccine jabs and more news of school districts fully reopening in the fall, its time for this issue to get back in the spotlight.

title: Day 10: Give Yourself a Break!
description: Are you as kind to yourself as you are to others? Take a self-compassion break. Ask yourself, What do I need right now? Then, do something nice for yourself: Take a walk or a hot bath. Call a friend for support. Adopt this mantra: Im going to be kind to myself. I accept myself as I am. Being good to ourselves makes us more likely to adopt healthy behaviors.

title: A Good Kind of Upstaging
description: Its usually rare that anyone upstages Stephen S. Miller, or Mama Rose as hes known in some corners of the New York theater world. Outgoing and charismatic, he tends to be center of attention wherever he goes, even when hes not wielding a microphone as a cabaret performer. By contrast, Brian Geldin, is more of an introvert. I have always been more of a tight-lipped, dry sense of humor kind of guy, he said.

title: The U.S. May Never Hit the Herd Immunity Threshold. Thats OK.
description: Half of Americans have now received at least one dose of a Covid-19 vaccine, and with children ages 12 to 15 now eligible for immunizations, the United States appears to be getting the coronavirus pandemic under control. But despite the tremendous progress, its still not clear that the nation will ever truly reach the herd immunity threshold the point at which enough people in a population are immune to a pathogen to limit its spread.

title: Covids Deadliest Phase May Be Here Soon
description: If world leaders dont act now, the end of the Covid pandemic may come with a horrible form of herd immunity, as more transmissible variants that are taking hold around the world kill millions.

title: Feeling Socially Rusty? Try a Little Light Gossiping.
description: Go ahead, talk a little trash. Gossip may not be good for you, per se, but its deeply connected to human nature. And it might just help in navigating a post-pandemic world  at least in a social sense.

title: How to Buy Happiness (Responsibly)
description: Bring on the nationwide spending binge.

title: Pep Guardiola and the Ones That Got Away
description: Alex Ferguson could, when the mood took him, be gracious in defeat. Often, that was when he was at his most ruminative, his most considered, his most obliging in his praise of an opponent. In all his years at Manchester United, though, he was never quite so effusive as he was deep inside Wembley Stadium exactly a decade ago.

title: Why Are So Many of My Fellow Health Workers Unvaccinated?
description: In April of last year, I along with my entire family  my husband, my three children, in-laws and at least one of our four home health aides  came down with Covid-19. The domino effect of household transmission was like a spark that set our house on fire. It was one of the most frightening experiences of my life  and I am an infectious disease epidemiologist who responded to the Ebola outbreak in 2014.

title: The Forgotten Queer Legacy of Billy West and Zuni Caf
description: In 2013 Judy Rodgers, the 57-year-old chef of Zuni Caf in San Francisco, yielded at last to the rare appendix cancer shed struggled with for more than a year. The many published tributes to Ms. Rodgers celebrated the urgent beauty in her deceptively simple dishes: the way Zunis roast chicken, house-cured anchovies and Caesar salad were woven into memories of perfect meals.

title: At Empty Bases, Echoes of War
description: In 2008, I was a Marine lance corporal. I was 20 years old. I graduated from high school in 2006. George W. Bush was president. I owned an iPod and a flip phone. It was my first deployment to Afghanistan. I wanted to buy the new Weezer album (the Red Album, featuring Pork and Beans) and watch Forgetting Sarah Marshall when I got back.

title: A Trump Case Awaits. Who Is the Best Prosecutor for the Job?
description: During its 20 year run, Law & Order cast five different actors in the role of Manhattan district attorney, a rate of turnover that feels like science fiction given that, in reality, four people have been elected to the office in 83 years. For the past 46 of them, the position, one of the most important prosecutorial posts in the country, has been held by two people, each an aristocrat born to a political dynasty: First, Robert M. Morgenthau, son of Henry Morgenthau Jr., who served as treasury secretary under two presidents (and who was himself the son of the United States ambassador to the Ottoman Empire); and since 2010, Cy Vance, son of the former secretary of state for whom he is named.

title: How a Photographer for the Downtown Alliance Spends His Sundays
description: Josh Katz, a photographer and content creator, has just started his second big project of the pandemic.

title: How Ranked-Choice Voting Could Affect New Yorks Mayoral Race
description: The competition for the Democratic mayoral nomination in New York City is wide open. Its the kind of race that ranked-choice voting is meant to help, by letting voters support their top choice without forfeiting the opportunity to weigh in on the most viable candidates.

title: When a Good First Impression Lingers
description: When Christine Sun and Michael Hurwitz first encountered each other, at a party hosted by the University of Virginia business school in 2015, they talked for a few minutes and both came away from the conversation a little surprised.

title: 70 Percent Covid Vaccination Rate May Be in Reach, New Poll Suggests
description: A new poll suggests the United States could be on track to vaccinate at least 70 percent of the adult population against Covid-19 by this summer.

title: Bidens Fossil Fuel Moves Clash With Pledges on Climate Change
description: WASHINGTON  Despite President Bidens pledge to aggressively cut the pollution from fossil fuels that is driving climate change, his administration has quietly taken actions this month that will guarantee the drilling and burning of oil and gas for decades to come.

title: Will the Next Space-Weather Season Be Stormy or Fair?
description: The big news about the sun is that there is no big news. We are blessed, astronomers like to say, to be living next to a boring star.

title: Where Your Watermelon Came From
description: About 4,300 years ago, someone drew a melon on the wall of a tomb in Egypt. Its big, fat, green and generously striped: Everything youd expect a watermelon to be. Its next to grapes and other fruits, suggesting it was eaten back then as we eat watermelon now, raw and for its sweet taste.

title: The Zombie-Mall Weirdness of Going to the Movies Again
description: Im finally back at Film Forum, watching porn. Not really. But I might as well be: Languorous, perfectly toned bodies writhe in La Piscine, the 1969 French erotic thriller taunting us from the screen. The stars, Alain Delon, Romy Schneider and Jane Birkin, are impossibly beautiful and shirtless. Party guests mingle, superspreading their way to bad decisions. The flirting is criminal.

title: Still Here and Still Queer: The Gay Restaurant Endures
description: Scott Frankels favorite memories of New York gay restaurants arent about food.

title: The Market Tectonics of California Real Estate
description: Jameel Khalfan, 36, and his wife, Shikha Mittal, 34, loved their two-bedroom apartment in East Cut, a walkable little square of high rises and urban energy in San Franciscos SoMa neighborhood. Ms. Mittal, a lawyer at the software company Databricks, walked the two blocks to her office every morning. Mr. Khalfan, who does business development at Google, took the company shuttle to his office in Mountain View four days a week, and on Fridays, when he worked from Googles San Francisco office, had his own two-minute walking commute.

title: Europes Dilemma: Take In ISIS Families, or Leave Them in Syria?
description: When Belgium said in March that it would repatriate some women who had joined the Islamic State, along with their children, Jessie Van Eetvelde welcomed the decision with relief  even though she knows it will likely mean time in prison.

title: For F9, Making Stunts That Stick
description: Theyve launched cars into the sky from the backs of planes. Theyve jumped cars through buildings in Abu Dhabi, theyve raced cars on sheets of ice and pitted them against submarines. Whats next for the filmmakers of the Fast and Furious series, a franchise that, for 20 years, has been a magnet for audiences?

title: How the First Black Female Jockey Rode Into Oblivion
description: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

title: Mmmm, Tastes Like America
description: The Blizzard was an instant hit when Dairy Queen introduced it in 1985. Dairy Queens Blizzard Is Hot, The New York Times reported the next year, crediting the delicacy with boosting the companys stock price and sales of mix-ins, like Heath bars.

title: A Big Climate Problem With Few Easy Solutions: Planes
description: The worst of the pandemic may be over for airlines, but the industry faces another looming crisis: an accounting over its contribution to climate change.

title: Summer Movies 2021: Heres Whats Coming to the Big (and Small) Screen
description: Here is a list of noteworthy films scheduled this summer. Release dates and platform are subject to change and reflect the latest information as of deadline.

title: The U.S. heads into another pandemic summer, but this time with optimism.
description: Ahead of Memorial Day a year ago, many officials in the United States had canceled parades and banned crowded gatherings. The country was on the cusp of recording 100,000 deaths from the coronavirus.

title: The U.K. approves the use of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine.
description: Britains drug regulator on Friday approved the use of the single-dose shots manufactured by Johnson & Johnson, the fourth coronavirus vaccine to be authorized in the country.

title: A Nuns Reminder of Mortality, a Hard-Won Love Story and Americas First Black Female Jockey: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

title: Final Day to Register to Vote in N.Y.C. Primary Elections
description: [Want to get New York Today by email? Heres the sign-up.]

title: California will give away $116.5 million to vaccinated residents.
description: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California on Thursday announced a $116.5 million giveaway to residents who receive a coronavirus vaccination, the latest and largest such effort among U.S. states seeking to motivate people to get a shot.

title: He Came to Berlin to Change the World. Then the World Changed Berlin.
description: BERLIN  Not long ago, Sir Henry stood on the main stage of the Volksbhne theater in what was once East Berlin and conducted the cosmos.

title: Day X, Part 1: Shadow Army?
description: This episode contains strong language.

title: At Naval Academy Graduation, Harris Focuses on Strengthening a Fragile World
description: WASHINGTON  Vice President Kamala Harris achieved another first for women on Friday when she addressed the graduating class of the United States Naval Academy, becoming the first female commencement speaker in the schools nearly 175-year history.

title: A Park Slope Mansion for $30 Million
description: A palatial house has a long history in the neighborhood.

title: A Historic Brooklyn Mansion Goes on the Market for $30 Million
description: The palatial, four-story mansion at 53 Prospect Park West, with a sprawling garden and a pair of pedestaled lions keeping guard out front, has had a long, rich history in Park Slope, Brooklyn.

title: India is in talks to obtain 50 million doses of the Pfizer vaccine.
description: The Indian government is in talks with Pfizer to obtain 50 million doses of the companys coronavirus vaccine starting this summer, but is still considering the drug manufacturers demand for indemnity from costs related to severe side effects, officials have said.

title: Japan extends a state of emergency until one month before the Olympics.
description: The Japanese government on Friday extended a state of emergency in Tokyo and eight other prefectures until at least June 20, barely one month before the city is scheduled to host the Olympic Games.

title: Fixing What Highways Destroyed
description: By the 1940s, the Los Angeles neighborhood of West Adams was turning into a thriving, racially integrated community.

title: Idahos governor repeals the lieutenant governors ban on mask mandates.
description: Idahos governor, Brad Little, said on Friday that he had repealed a ban on mask mandates that a political rival, Lt. Gov. Janice McGeachin, had issued while he was traveling out of state for a conference of the Republican Governors Association.

title: A Perfect Match Written In the Stars
description: With so little to do in April 2020, Danielle Lavey and Drew Feldman quickly learned they had easy banter. That was enough for them to keep the conversation going.

title: When a Two-Week Stay Becomes a Permanent Move
description: Samuel Parker gave Madeline Hollander a piece of jewelry before they had gone on even a single date. It was an earring she had lost at La Caverna, a club in the Lower East Side of Manhattan, where they were both celebrating the opening of the 2019 Whitney Biennial.

title: In Spain, with the virus easing, a debate continues over access to testing.
description: The government in Spain ended the Covid-19 state of emergency on May 9. The countrys inoculation campaign is accelerating. And Prime Minister Pedro Snchez recently predicted that 70 percent of the population of 47 million would be vaccinated by mid-August.

title: Scenes From a Moguls Marriage or: The Troubling Fourth Act of Bill Gates
description: Three years ago, Bill and Melinda Gates answered a range of personal questions in their annual letter  a rare peek into what kept one of the worlds most powerful couples together.

title: JD Logistics, the delivery arm of the Chinese e-commerce giant, gains in its I.P.O.
description: JD Logistics, a supply chain unit of JD.com, the big Chinese internet retailer, raised more than $3.1 billion in a share listing in Hong Kong on Friday, the latest Chinese company to raise money in a record-breaking year for the citys stock exchange.

title: Inside Exxons Board Fight
description: Exxon Mobils defeat by a new activist investor, Engine No. 1, at its annual meeting on Wednesday is still reverberating around Wall Street. Shareholders voting against management to install at least two new board members is seen as both a milestone for climate-focused investing and the emergence of a new force in shareholder activism. DealBook has the behind-the-scenes dish on the most important moments in the battle.

title: Anthony Davis and the Lakers Are Back on Their Feet
description: LOS ANGELES  It was not an especially pleasant night of basketball for Anthony Davis. Productive? Yes. Pleasant? No.

title: Decluttering for a Renovation
description: Of all the random objects residing in my kitchen drawers, the truffle shaver is probably the most absurd. Ive cooked with fresh truffles once, long before I lived in this house. I bought this slim, metal blade at the now closed Dean & Deluca in SoHo with my husband before he was my husband. We were living in our first apartment together in Brooklyn and had the good fortune of spare time and money.

title: The Hollywood Bowl Is Now on Plan C: Filling All 18,000 Seats
description: LOS ANGELES  They are playing ball at Dodger Stadium, with all 56,000 seats on sale for games beginning next month, and not an inch of social distance between them. Across the country, Radio City Music Hall in New York is flinging open its doors and selling 5,960 shoulder-to-shoulder seats to the vaccinated in a decidedly indoor setting.

title: Friends Reunion Is Censored in China, Cutting BTS and Lady Gaga
description: In China, the reunion episode of Friends was all about grudges.

title: A vaccine mandate unleashed a mob in a small Polish town.
description: A small but menacing rally this month in Poland followed a decision a few days earlier by the elected council in Walbrzych, a former mining town in the southwestern part of the country, to declare that vaccination against the coronavirus was mandatory for all adult residents.

title: AMC shares whipsaw as retail investors swarm.
description: Shares of AMC, the movie theater chain, surged more than 30 percent in early trading Friday before erasing all of those gains, as the whirlwind trading of small investors returned.By the end of the day on Friday, AMC was down 1.5 percent. But, including Fridays drop, AMC shares jumped 116 percent this week.The trading is reminiscent of the GameStop frenzy in January. One of the aims of the retail traders is to push up a companys share price to force losses on hedge funds that have bet against the stock in what is called a short squeeze. At the end of 2019, before AMC became a meme stock darling like GameStop, the video game retailer, and Blackberry, the phone company, the share price for AMC was about $2.GameStop slid 12 percent on Friday, but climbed about 26 percent for the week.

title: Prices jumped 3.6 percent in April, the fastest pace in 13 years.
description: Prices are climbing at the fastest pace since 2008, a key index released on Friday showed, an increase that is sure to keep inflation central to economic and political debates.

title: How Do You Teach 6-Year-Olds Their Legal Rights?
description: Good morning.

title: How to Tell if a Companys Claim of Ethical Practices Is True
description: Vital Farms says on its website that its eggs and butter are delicious, ethical food you dont have to question.

title: Interest Rates on Federal Student Loans Will Rise in July
description: Students attending college in the fall will pay higher interest rates than last year on money borrowed to finance their education.

title: Film or Real Life?
description: When Jake Michaels began shooting around Los Angeles, he noticed how the backdrop and spontaneous action within the frame combine to tell a story, and how those moments dissolve quickly. Thats why I think its interesting to go back to a place several times, Michaels said. You can see life kind of cycling. You see from a static point of view how much life exists in that frame.

title: Pride Said Gay Cops Arent Welcome. Then Came the Backlash.
description: It was two weeks before the start of Pride month, and the organization that runs New Yorks Pride march was fighting about cops. The leadership had just announced that officers could no longer take part in the march, including a contingent of L.G.B.T.Q. officers that has marched in uniform since 1996.

title: How Exxon Lost a Board Battle With a Small Hedge Fund
description: Early this year, leaders of Exxon Mobil, the vast oil company descended from the Standard Oil empire, found themselves in an unusual situation: defending the oil giant against a tiny activist investor calling for a major shake-up in the name of climate change. Even more unusually, they were on the back foot.

title: Cruella | Anatomy of a Scene
description: The director Craig Gillespie narrates a sequence from his film featuring Emma Stone and Emma Thompson.

title: The Indie-Rock Duo Bachelor Finds Comfort, but Not Escape, in the 90s
description: Bachelor is an indie-rock alliance that makes perfect sense. Melina Duterte, who records as Jay Som, and Ellen Kempner, who leads Palehound, met  inevitably  on tour, sharing a double bill in 2017. That booking recognized how compatible theyd be: two breathy-voiced songwriters whose music can be fragile or bruising, offering both vulnerability and resolve.

title: A Beloved London Concert Hall Grows Bold as It Turns 120
description: LONDON  Welcome! said John Gilhooly, the general director of the Wigmore Hall, standing in front of the auditoriums small circular stage. The audience applauded wildly  for a crowd of chamber music fans.

title: Watch Emma Stone Become Cruella
description: In Anatomy of a Scene, we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

title: The federal housing agency plans to help Black homeowners as part of its racial justice agenda.
description: Housing Secretary Marcia Fudge is planning a broad new effort to fight housing discrimination that includes a $100 million initiative intended to spur Black homeownership in areas historically off-limits to minorities, administration officials briefed on the plan said.

title: Boeing puts off 787 deliveries again to provide more information to the F.A.A.
description: Boeing said Friday that it was providing the Federal Aviation Administration with extra information related to inspections of its 787 Dreamliner, further delaying deliveries of the plane.

title: Errol Morris: What We Believe About Beliefs
description: This personal reflection is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: What do we believe? You can read more essays by visiting The Big Ideas series page.

title: 7 Podcasts to Soothe Your Back-to-Normal Anxiety
description: We have collectively lived through a global trauma thats going to take years, maybe even decades, to process. With vaccination rates in the United States rising and infection rates plummeting, most of the Covid-19 restrictions weve become used to are disappearing, while all the forbidden fruits weve learned to live without  from indoor dining to air travel to large gatherings  are once again within our grasps.

title: Natalie Morales Makes Her Directing Debut. Twice.
description: If the pandemic had a silver lining for Natalie Morales, its that she got to spend part of a summer lockdown in Los Angeles directing Language Lessons, a low-budget, character-driven movie that she co-wrote and starred in with Mark Duplass, one of her filmmaking heroes.

title: What Is a Summit?
description: Only 44 people are said to have reached the summit of all 14 of the worlds highest mountains. Now, researchers are questioning whether any of them have really done it.

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Good morning. Maybe youll spend the Memorial Day weekend preparing to picnic, or getting ready to cook outside, or setting yourself up for a potluck. Perhaps youll make sandwiches and take them on a long walk in the woods or along a beach, up an avenue, across town on a quiet side street, toward a park. I hope so. Its good to cook for others. Its good to eat outside.

title: Great Ideas From Our Readers
description: Do you use The New York Times in your classroom? Whether youre a teacher, parent, coach, librarian, tutor, counselor, adviser, administrator or even a student, we want to hear about your idea for teaching or learning with The Times.

title: Revisiting Ilkay Gundogan
description: Ilkay Gundogan is a little sheepish as he admits it. It is not what he is supposed to do, he knows. He is supposed to take each game as it comes. That is the professionals mantra. Dont get ahead of yourself. Think about today, rather than tomorrow. That is what a sports psychologist would advise. It is what his manager, certainly, would recommend.

title: DMXs Posthumous All-Star Track, and 9 More New Songs
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

title: Five New Horror Movies to Stream Now
description: A Quiet Place Part II and Spiral: From the Book of Saw, are hogging the horror movie spotlight in theaters at the moment. But on streaming, these five under-the-radar horror films should be elbowing their way onto your watch list.

title: The Newest Player on the High School Basketball Court: High Tech
description: When Natalia Chavez hit a half-court buzzer-beater in overtime to help Volcano Vista High School win the New Mexico state championship this month, her shot went viral on the internet and became one of ESPNs top plays.

title: A Black Composers Intense Opera Gets a Rare Staging
description: The composer William Grant Still was a student of the renowned experimentalist Edgard Varse, an arranger for the blues icon W.C. Handy and the creator of the enduringly winning Afro-American Symphony. Thanks to his rich catalog of symphonic and chamber music, Still, who died in 1978 at 83, was widely known as the pathbreaking dean of Black American composers.

title: Tribes to Confront Bias Against Descendants of Enslaved People
description: With pressure growing from the Biden administration, two Native American tribes in Oklahoma have agreed to consider reversing their policies of denying citizenship to descendants of Black people who were enslaved by them before the Civil War.

title: At Long Last, a New Rail Tunnel Under the Hudson River Can Be Built
description: For five years, the plan to build a second pair of rail tunnels between New York City and New Jersey has been deemed one of the most critical infrastructure projects in the country.

title: Alex Hay, Comeback Painter
description: A half-century on, Alex Hays giant paint-and-canvas homages to items usually found in stationery stores continue to amuse and amaze. His 1965 painting Legal Pad lives up to its title, with the pale yellow of the paper and the pale blue of the delicate horizontal lines running edge to edge. It might almost be the real thing, except that, at nearly 8 feet tall, it looms. Its combination of precise realism and outsize scale encapsulates the conundrum of Hays art: It is both commanding and modest, stately and slightly comic.

title: The Best of Late Night This Week
description: Jimmy Kimmel and Ted Cruz rekindled an old feud, and the late-night hosts riffed on Donald Trump, vaccine reluctance and Brian Kemp's blunder.

title: Krugman Wonks Out: The Greenback Rules. So What?
description: This article is a wonky edition of Paul Krugmans free newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it.

title: Move Over, Ricotta. This Pasta Gets Its Creaminess From Cottage Cheese.
description: Long before my ancestors ever met macaroni and cheese or a plate of spaghetti, noodles with cottage cheese was the pasta comfort food in my Brooklyn Ashkenazi Jewish family.

title: There Is So Much You Dont Know About Being a Fly
description: SUPER FLYThe Unexpected Lives of the Worlds Most Successful InsectsBy Jonathan Balcombe

title: Spain Issued Equality Stamps in Skin Tones. The Darker Ones Were Worth Less.
description: MADRID  A new campaign by Spains postal service that was intended to condemn racism has backfired and ended up offending many people with a series of stamps in skin tones  the lighter the shade, the more valuable the stamp.

title: Social Security Is Rethinking How It Runs Customer Service After Covid
description: When the pandemic struck last year, the Social Security Administration shut down its national network of more than 1,200 offices as it scrambled to protect the public and its employees from the coronavirus.

title: Was 1971 the Year Music Changed Everything?
description: Everything changed with the music of 1971. No, wait. It was 1973. Check that  1974 was the year, except it was music, film and television, but only in Los Angeles.

title: Democrats failed to get enough votes for an independent inquiry into the Jan. 6 riot.
description: Republicans on Friday blocked the creation of an independent commission to investigate the Jan. 6 Capitol riot, using their filibuster power in the Senate for the first time this year to doom a full accounting for the deadliest attack on Congress in centuries.

title: Rusty Warren, Brash Comic in a Strait-Laced Time, Dies at 91
description: Rusty Warren started out in the early 1950s performing harmless fare in bars and clubs in the Boston area and the Catskills.

title: A History of the Book Review Through Its Fonts
description: The editors of the Book Review, which was founded in 1896, liked to tinker with its appearance in its early years. Although photos already appeared in other parts of the paper, these came only later to the Book Review. The publication turned instead to typography  some of it quite fanciful  to set its distinctive-looking pages apart.

title: One Thing Missing From the Biden Budget: Booming Growth
description: President Bidens budget proposal includes billions of dollars for clean energy, education and child care  ideas being sold for their potential to increase Americas economic potential. One thing it does not include: an outright economic boom.

title: A Grilled Shrimp Feast, Best Enjoyed Outdoors
description: Summer is the best time to eat outdoors, and, when eating outside coincides with cooking outdoors, so much the better.

title: Harris Delivers Naval Academy Commencement Speech
description: Vice President Kamala Harris became the first female commencement speaker in the United States Naval Academys nearly 175-year history on Friday. Her speech focused on the challenges and opportunities of the modern era.

title: Small Earthquakes Rattle Lake Tahoe Area
description: At least six small earthquakes, including one with a preliminary magnitude of 4.2, shook the Lake Tahoe, Reno and Carson City area early on Friday, according to the U.S. Geological Survey.

title: Facebook Takes on Superspreaders
description: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

title: Mustafa, a Folk Hero for a Weary Generation
description: LOS ANGELES  In the middle of Mustafas potent, chilling and heart-rending debut EP, When Smoke Rises, is The Hearse, a startling two-minute meditation on revenge in the wake of a friends murder.

title: Fox News Intensifies Its Pro-Trump Politics as Dissenters Depart
description: Fox News once devoted its 7 p.m. and 11 p.m. time slots to relatively straightforward newscasts. Now those hours are filled by opinion shows led by hosts who denounce Democrats and defend the worldview of former President Donald J. Trump.

title: The Weekender
description: The talking dog of TikTok. A 70-year-old cold case in Australia. An interview with Emma Stone. The future of Caribbean tourism. And more.

title: A Brilliant Burger and Other Inspired Recipes
description: When I was picking out this weeks recipes for you, I was dreaming of Memorial Day weekend gatherings and the days that follow, that first big summer-vibe weekend of the year. (By the way, our Food staffs favorite recipes for the season are right here in this amazing feature.)

title: Bidens $6 Trillion Budget Aims for Path to Middle Class, Financed by the Rich
description: WASHINGTON  President Bidens $6 trillion budget bets on the power of government to propel workers, families and businesses to new heights of prosperity in a rapidly changing economy, by redistributing income and wealth from high earners and corporations to grow the middle class.

title: A Look at Whats Inside Bidens $6 Trillion Budget Request
description: President Bidens first budget request maps out a vision of an expansive federal government in the years to come, with increased spending in areas like infrastructure, education and climate change.

title: A Worker-Owned Cooperative Tries to Compete With Uber and Lyft
description: For years, Uber and other ride-hailing companies offered the promise of entrepreneurship to drivers. Drivers who were eager to set their own schedules signed up in droves, propelling the gig economy into a multibillion-dollar industry.

title: Alix Dobkin, Who Sang Songs of Liberation, Dies at 80
description: Long before K.D. Lang transformed herself from a  country artist into an androgyne pop idol and sex symbol, smoldering in a mans suit on the cover of Vanity Fair being mock-shaved by the supermodel Cindy Crawford; long before Melissa Etheridge sold millions of copies of her 1993 album, Yes I Am, and in so doing came out as a gay rock star; and long before the singer-songwriter Jill Sobules I Kissed a Girl hit the Billboard charts, the folk singer Alix Dobkin chopped her hair off, formed a band and recorded Lavender Jane Loves Women.

title: G.O.P. dissent delays passage of China competitiveness bill until June.
description: An expansive, $195 billion bill aimed at bolstering the nations competitive edge against China hit a snag in the Senate on Friday, after a small group of Republicans objected to its swift passage, pushing a vote on the bipartisan legislation until next month.

title: Poor Americans More Likely to Have Respiratory Problems, Study Finds
description: In recent decades, air quality has improved in the United States, smoking rates have plummeted and government safety regulations have reduced exposure to workplace pollutants. But rich and poor Americans have not benefited equally, scientists reported in a paper on Friday.

title: Touching the Void Review: Choices That Shape a Life on the Edge
description: Many movies, books or shows are metaphorical slogs. The play Touching the Void is about a literal one: the slow, agonizing crawl of the British mountaineer Joe Simpson as he tried to return to his base camp after sustaining a gruesome injury on an Andes peak.

title: A judge orders the appointment of a special master to review devices the F.B.I. seized from Giuliani.
description: A federal judge in Manhattan on Friday ordered the appointment of a so-called special master to review whether materials seized from Rudolph W. Giulianis apartment and office during an F.B.I. search in April are protected by attorney-client privilege.

title: Horrible History: Mass Grave of Indigenous Children Reported in Canada
description: OTTAWA  For decades, most Indigenous children in Canada were taken from their families and forced into boarding schools. A large number never returned home, their families given only vague explanations, or none at all.

title: Traveling This Memorial Day Weekend? Pack Patience.
description: Last year, for the first time in 20 years, AAA, the automobile owners group, declined to put out its annual Memorial Day travel forecast as the surging coronavirus pandemic kept many people close to home.

title: Love Letter: Her Late Mothers Love
description: The death of a parent can be a devastating and life-altering experience, especially for a child.

title: A Desperate Writer Steals The Plot
description: Jake Bonner, the protagonist of Jean Hanff Korelitzs The Plot, writes a novel based on someone elses idea. The book becomes a big hit, but Jake has a hard time enjoying it because hes worried about getting caught. On this weeks podcast, Korelitz says that Jakes more general anxieties about his career as a writer are relatable, despite her own success (this is her seventh novel).

title: The European Unions drug regulator approved the Pfizer vaccine for children 12 to 15 years old.
description: The European Medicines Agency approved on Friday the use of the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine for children aged 12 to 15, in what the drug regulator called an important step forward in the fight against the pandemic in a statement.

title: People Want an Alzheimers Drug. This Isnt the One.
description: In early June, the Food and Drug Administration will decide whether to approve a treatment for Alzheimers disease, which today affects more than five million Americans, with millions more at risk over the next decade. The decision will be consequential, because it will set the bar for market entry and define standards of care against which future drug candidates will be tested.

title: San Jose Holds Vigil for Victims of Rail Yard Shooting
description: Hundreds gathered outside City Hall in San Jose, Calif., on Thursday evening to memorialize the nine transit authority employees who were killed by a co-worker at the rail yard the day before.

title: Real Peace Depends on Recognizing Israels Right to Exist
description: At a news conference recently President Biden made a statement that might have seemed unremarkable: Lets get something straight here, Mr. Biden said. Until the region says unequivocally, they acknowledge the right of Israel to exist as an independent Jewish state, there will be no peace.

title: Times Journalist Weighs Legal Action Against University of North Carolina
description: The board of trustees at the University of North Carolina is under intensifying pressure to grant tenure to Nikole Hannah-Jones, the Pulitzer Prize-winning New York Times Magazine journalist who is scheduled to start as a professor at its journalism school in July.

title: Equity Firm Founder Sentenced to Two Months in College Admissions Scandal
description: A private equity executive accused of paying $40,000 to have someone secretly correct his daughters ACT exam answers was sentenced Thursday to two months in prison, the latest term handed down in the nationwide college admissions scandal that embroiled a handful of wealthy parents, including Hollywood actresses and business executives.

title: What to Do This Weekend
description: Welcome. At Home was born in March 2020, as part of The Timess effort to help readers lead full and cultured lives at home during the coronavirus pandemic. We replaced the Travel section in the Sunday newspaper with an At Home section and launched this newsletter, hoping to be of service, to offer ideas for how to pass the time and make sense of a world that seemed, too often, wholly senseless.

title: Does the Devil Wear Prada in Indiana?
description: CARMEL, Ind.  What do the performers Christy Altomare and Corey Cott do during a weekend in this midsize Central Indiana city in between workshops for a Broadway-aimed musical?

title: Part 1: Shadow Army?
description: A German military officer is arrested with a loaded gun and turns out to be part of a nationwide network of far-right extremists.

title: Fears for Bangladesh Garment Workers as Safety Agreement Nears an End
description: Since the Rana Plaza disaster in 2013, in which a Dhaka factory collapse killed more than 1,100 people, Bangladesh has gone from being the global poster child for garment worker tragedies to a reformation success story.

title: Iran Clears Way for Hard-line Judiciary Chief to Become President
description: Candidates in Irans presidential elections have always been strictly vetted, and those deemed insufficiently loyal to the Islamic Revolution were disqualified. Within those limits, contenders held differing views on easing domestic restrictions or dealing with the West, and sometimes the victor was even a surprise.

title: The Daily: Wheres Michael?
description: Youve probably noticed something different about The Daily over the past few weeks.

title: Senate Republicans Filibuster Jan. 6 Inquiry Bill, Blocking an Investigation
description: WASHINGTON  Republicans on Friday blocked the creation of an independent commission to investigate the Jan. 6 Capitol riot, using their filibuster power in the Senate for the first time this year to doom a full accounting of the deadliest attack on Congress in centuries.

title: Lobbyist Closely Tied to N.Y. Assembly Speaker Draws Federal Scrutiny
description: Federal prosecutors have subpoenaed a top New York lobbyist closely tied to Assembly Speaker Carl E. Heastie and sought records from at least two of his clients and a state agency in recent weeks, according to people with knowledge of the inquiry.

title: Faye Schulman Dies; Fought Nazis With a Rifle and a Camera
description: On Aug. 14, 1942, a year after German troops invaded Soviet-occupied Poland, they massacred the last 1,850 Jews from a shtetl named Lenin near the Sluch River. Only 27 were spared, their skills deemed essential by the invaders.

title: Biden recognizes the sacrifice of service members in a speech ahead of Memorial Day.
description: President Biden delivered an emotional speech on Friday honoring the sacrifice of combat veterans ahead of the planned withdrawal later this year from Afghanistan  and recalled his many trips to a battle-scarred country he called God-forsaken.

title: The Republicans and the Jan. 6 Commission
description: To the Editor:

title: California to Give $116.5 million to Vaccinated Residents
description: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California announced on Thursday a $116.5 million giveaway to residents who have received a coronavirus vaccination in an effort to motivate people to get a shot.

title: Reading Dan Frank, Book Editor and Champion of the Unexampled
description: Summer is basically here, and now is the moment to find a book to fall into.

title: I Want to Invest in My Wardrobe. Help!
description: All I can say is: Youre a lot more forward-thinking than I was at your age. And more important, what you are thinking about is what may be the single most effective thing any of us can do when it comes to fashion and climate change: laying the building blocks of a sustainable wardrobe  that is, one that lasts over time and is not disposable.

title: The C.D.C. says unvaccinated children at U.S. camps can go without masks most of the time when they are outside.
description: Federal health officials are encouraging young people aged 12 and over who are heading to camp this summer to get vaccinated against the coronavirus as soon as possible, saying on Friday that camps where all staff and campers are vaccinated can drop many Covid restrictions, including masks, and return to full capacity. Unvaccinated children can also go without masks most of the time when they are outside because the risk of transmission outdoors is low.

title: Christopher Stone, Who Proposed Legal Rights for Trees, Dies at 83
description: Christopher D. Stone, who in 1972 made what seemed a whimsical argument  that forests and rivers should have rights in the eyes of the law  and in the following decades found his work galvanizing environmental lawyers in the United States and launching a global movement to grant nature the legal status of personhood, died on May 14 at an assisted living facility in Los Angeles. He was 83.

title: At the French Open, Naomi Osaka Seeks Comfort on Clay and No Interviews
description: PARIS  While other major players juggled practice and media commitments ahead of the French Open, Naomi Osaka focused only on practice this week.

title: 5 Songs to Listen to Right Now
description: Here are five new and notable songs, including Sleater-Kinneys latest and Nicki Minajs rap reunion with Drake and Lil Wayne.

title: Covid Shuttered Schools Everywhere. So Why Was the She-cession Worse in the U.S.?
description: Matthias Doepke, an economist at Northwestern, on whats causing the global she-cession

title: Capitol Riot, Memorial Day, French Open: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Heres the sign-up.)

title: So, You Want to Mingle Outdoors This Summer?
description: During spring break last month, Monica Gandhi tested her confidence in coronavirus science. She and her two unvaccinated children stood in a packed crowd near a well-known bridge in Austin, Texas, to enjoy watching the emergence at dusk of thousands of Brazilian free-tailed bats.

title: An Israeli Death and the Tangled Conflict Left Behind
description: RAMAT GAN, Israel  Four holes in the wooden door to his tiny apartment mark where shrapnel from a Hamas rocket penetrated the home of Gershon Franco, 56, and killed him. It was the early afternoon of May 15, a Saturday, the Sabbath in this bustling town just east of Tel Aviv.

title: Biden Honors Service Members Ahead of Memorial Day
description: President Biden addressed military members at Joint Base Langley-Eustis in Virginia on Friday, honoring the sacrifices of combat veterans and looking toward the planned withdrawal from Afghanistan later this year.

title: Farmworker Convicted of Fatally Stabbing Iowa College Student
description: A farmworker was found guilty of first-degree murder on Friday in the fatal stabbing of a University of Iowa student who had vanished while jogging in 2018, a case that briefly inflamed the national debate over immigration.

title: Game Over
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  The visual element in this theme is such a delight! Im not ashamed to say that I got butterflies in my stomach when I discovered it. Adam Wagner is a new constructor (two daily grids, both this April) and a new dad (as of only about two months, so Mr. Wagners having a fairly eventful Q2 of 2021, one could say). According to the puzzles print introduction, his new baby is already solving the daily crossword every night at home in San Francisco, presumably with a little help from Pop; that could make for an impressive lifelong solving streak.

title: Early analysis suggests that another mRNA vaccine is safe, but its effectiveness isnt yet known.
description: The German company CureVac said on Friday that its Covid-19 vaccine had passed its first interim analysis, but that it was not yet ready to share data on how well it protects against infection. The shot could be cheaper and more accessible to low-income countries that lack vaccines.

title: Why Biden Isnt Cracking Down on Fossil Fuels
description: Picture this predicament, described by our climate reporter Lisa Friedman in her latest article as a paradox worthy of Kafka: In order to break through the earth and tap the oil in the National Petroleum Reserve in Alaska, ConocoPhillips must install chillers into the thawing permafrost.

title: Carla Fracci, Expressive Doyenne of Italian Ballet, Dies at 84
description: Carla Fracci, Italys grande dame of ballet and one of the greatest ballerinas of the 20th century, who was admired for the naturalness and emotional directness of her performances, died on Thursday  at her home in Milan. She was 84.

title: Biden Banks on $3.6 Trillion Tax Hike on the Rich and Corporations
description: WASHINGTON  President Biden on Friday unveiled $3.6 trillion in tax increases on wealthy Americans and big corporations to pay for his plans to combat climate change, reduce income inequality and significantly expand the nations social safety net.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: The Memorial Day weekend is typically the unofficial start of summer, but this year it could represent so much more: the return of optimism in the U.S.

title: National Endowment for the Arts Funding Would Rise Under Biden Plan
description: After four years when the National Endowment for the Arts lived under the threat of elimination, President Biden on Friday proposed a 20 percent increase in the budget for the agency to $201 million.

title: Her High School Said She Ranked Third in Her Class. So She Went to Court.
description: Dalee Sullivan looked straight ahead into her computers camera and started making her case to the judge. She referred to transcripts, emails and policies she had pulled from the student handbook at Alpine High School. The school, she contended, had made errors in tabulating grade-point averages: Classes and exams that should have been included were left out, and vice versa.

title: What to Know About Booking Travel to Europe
description: Now that vaccinated Americans can soon travel to Europe, the masterpieces of the Louvre and the beaches of Sicily once again feel within reach. Heres what to consider.

title: Democrat or Republican, You Probably Love the Post Office
description: Last year, in the midst of a presidential election campaign and a pandemic, the U.S. Postal Service was politicized by President Donald Trump and his administration as had never been done before. Critics accused the postmaster general, Louis DeJoy, of making changes to mail delivery to increase Mr. Trumps chances of re-election, a charge he vehemently denied.

title: Guilty Verdict in the Killing of Mollie Tibbietts
description: A jury found Cristhian Bahena Rivera guilty of first-degree murder in the death of Ms. Tibbetts, a University of Iowa student who vanished while jogging in 2018.

title: Anniversary Event for Tulsa Race Massacre Unraveled Over Reparations
description: In a weekend of events commemorating the 100th anniversary of the Tulsa Race Massacre, one scheduled for Memorial Day at the citys minor league baseball stadium was to have been a main attraction. It was to be televised, with John Legend performing, and Stacey Abrams giving the keynote speech before thousands.

title: Zimbabwe Authorities Arrest Local Reporter Working for The New York Times
description: The authorities in Zimbabwe have arrested a freelance reporter who works for The New York Times and accused him of improperly helping two other Times journalists make a reporting trip there recently, his lawyers said Friday.

title: Postal Service, Facing Steep Losses, Seeks to Increase Prices
description: Americans would have to pay more to mail a letter under a series of price increases that the Postal Service proposed on Friday as part of a plan intended to reverse $160 billion in projected operating losses over the next decade.

title: Guilty Verdict in the Killing of Mollie Tibbetts
description: A jury found Cristhian Bahena Rivera guilty of first-degree murder in the death of Ms. Tibbetts, a University of Iowa student who vanished while jogging in 2018.

title: Low-Key
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  Theres a lot of cinematic action in this grid, which is Adam Aaronsons third puzzle and his third tricky Saturday for The Times. (His most recent one was with Paolo Pasco, the KRZYZEWSKI/KYRGYZSTAN construction from last summer.) Mr. Aaronson writes in his notes that hes a debut treasure hunter, and there are nine new entries today, including a few surprises, but theres nothing forced or flashy about todays solve.

title: Foster Friess, Big Donor to Republicans, Dies at 81
description: Foster Friess, a Wyoming businessman who founded an investment firm, made a fortune and gave a lot of it away to Republican presidential candidates and charities, sometimes with flair, died on Thursday in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 81.

title: Quotation of the Day: Biden Finds Fossil Fuels Hard to Quit
description: I get that theyre being pressured politically. I get that there are thin margins. But the climate crisis doesnt care about any of that stuff.

title: Corrections: May 29, 2021
description: An article on Tuesday about poets in Myanmar overstated what is known about the origin of lines from a poem read by Ko Khet Thi at another poets funeral. While he recited the poem, it is unknown if he wrote it.

title: Yankees Fall to Tigers in Extra Innings
description: DETROIT  Robbie Grossman hit a two-run homer in the bottom of the 10th inning to give the Detroit Tigers a 3-2 victory over the Yankees on Friday night.

title: A Week of Big Blows for Big Oil
description: For environmentalists, it was a week of victories. For the oil and gas companies they vanquished, as well as Alberta and the other parts of Canada that rely on the energy industry, the week brought new uncertainties.

title: Is the Montauk Party Over?
description: Before 2020, it was impossible to miss a wooden beach bar in Montauk called the Sloppy Tuna. Shoes and shirts were optional. Bikini-clad ladies and shirtless men would guzzle pia coladas on the deck. It was involved in numerous drug arrests and noise complaints.

title: As the Hamptons Boom, a New World of Luxury Problems
description: It was 4 p.m. last Friday and a 30-something New Yorker whod just flown into the East Hampton airport was seated on a bench outside the terminal, typing into his laptop, a pair of orange Hermes bags to his side.

title: Desperately Seeking Lifeguards for Hamptons Pools
description: The email pleas began in April. Pool lifeguard needed, one read. A beach club offered $200 a day and a room in Southampton. Another, the Hampton Boathouses, offered to pay $2 more an hour.

title: Big Setbacks Propel Oil Giants Toward a Tipping Point
description: A nun, an environmental lawyer, pension fund executives, and the worlds largest asset manager. These were among the unusual collection of rebels who claimed a series of startling victories this week against some of the worlds biggest and most influential fossil fuel companies.

title: U.S. to Reimpose Sanctions on Belarus Over Forced Plane Landing
description: The Biden administration said late Friday that it would reimpose economic sanctions on certain state-owned companies in Belarus, the latest diplomatic pushback from a Western government after the countrys authoritarian leader forced down a European passenger jet last weekend.

title: Eager Teens Give Needed Boost to U.S. Vaccination Campaign
description: More than 2.5 million tweens and teens have gotten their first shot, making up about a quarter of all new vaccinations in recent weeks.

title: Welcome to the Party of the Century. Leave Your Scruples at the Door.
description: MALIBU RISINGBy Taylor Jenkins Reid

title: Can You Hear Me Now, in the Hamptons?
description: Taryn Lawrence, 44, a stay-at-home mother who moved to Southampton Village six years ago, has plenty to say about cellphone reception in the area  if you can hear her. There have always been areas where you know your phone call will drop out, she said. But it started getting gradually worse.

title: Our Digital Pasts Werent Supposed to Be Weaponized Like This
description: The internet is a fossil machine. It preserves our thoughts, our political positions, our jokes, our photos, our triumphs and our mistakes in silicon amber, just waiting to be dug up. And that has led to a kind of modern sport: Find an outrageous piece of a persons past that can be weaponized, put it on display for all to see and hope for the worst.

title: How to Win a Bidding War Before It Starts
description: Q: My wife and I are trying to buy a house in Fairfield County, Conn., and we keep losing bidding wars. We offer over the asking price, but we cant pay in cash. How much do we need to offer to get a house? Is there a magic number, or is this a pipe dream and well never find one?

title: Benito Skinner Is All About Drama
description: Benito Skinner was born and raised in Boise, Idaho, but has long felt destined for Hollywood, by way of a stint in New York City.

title: 14 Excerpts from Commencement Speeches Without the Word C*vid
description: Commencement speeches can bleed together. Adversity: overcome. Mountains: climbed. Friendships: lifelong.

title: Summertime  and the Sloganeering Is a Little Awkward
description: They are the opening lines of a reopening: entreaties by cities, states and nations seeking to draw a wary public by evoking a sense of togetherness, normalcy and  lest anyone forget  fun.

title: Sedona Prince Has a Message for You
description: When Sedona Prince arrived in San Antonio in March for her first N.C.A.A. womens basketball tournament, she was grateful just to be playing again after a long recovery from an injury.

title: A Glut of Chinese Masks Is Driving U.S. Companies Out of Business
description: Mask mandates have eased, a welcome milestone in the battle against Covid-19. But for the two dozen domestic companies that jumped into the mask-making business last year, the good news comes with a downside: a calamitous drop in sales.

title: Their Olympics Are Already Canceled
description: A few years ago, Bud Kling had three rooms added to his house in the Pacific Palisades in California. The builders used extra concrete along with a reinforcing metal beam  and not because Mr. Kling was expecting a crowd. The rooms werent for people. They were designed to house and showcase his 30,000-strong collection of Olympic pins, the colorful and endlessly varied souvenirs that have been bought and traded at the Games for decades.

title: House Hunters Are Leaving the City, and Builders Cant Keep Up
description: LATHROP, Calif.  They had a down payment. They were prequalified for a mortgage. They were willing to move almost an hours drive eastward. But the number that really mattered was 32.

title: N.Y.C. Roads Are Busy Again, and So Are Traffic Reporters
description: Buzzing over New York City in a traffic helicopter on a morning in March of last year, Tom Kaminski, a radio traffic reporter for more than three decades, looked down at the rush hour commute. He gasped.

title: Manhattanhenge 2021: When and Where to Watch
description: For two days every spring and summer, the sunset lines up with Manhattans street grid, creating a gorgeous celestial spectacle. For a brief moment, the suns golden rays illuminate the citys buildings and traffic with a breathtaking glow.

title: The Fifty Shades of Grey Author Finishes What She Started (and Restarted)
description: For a novelist who became famous writing hard-core erotica, E L James is surprisingly introverted. Im incredibly shy under all of it, she said.

title: Unleashed but (Mostly) Masked, British Tourists Return to Portugal
description: After enduring a winter of strict lockdown, and a spring that saw a gradual reopening but lousy weather to spend it in, the first British tourists to Portugal since the country was green-listed for quarantine-free travel were elated by the thrill of escape, even if their trips were not quite as carefree as in past summers.

title: What Do I Do Next?: Orphaned by Covid, Two Teens Find Their Way
description: Their mother went into cardiac arrest just before midnight.

title: I Knew That I Couldnt Stay Quiet
description: Last summer, millions of Americans took to the streets after the killing of George Floyd at the hands of the Minneapolis police, taking part in what would become the largest protest movement in U.S. history. Many participated in marches and demonstrations for the first time in their lives. From eight first-time protesters, here are reflections on what they did last summer, how this has affected them in the year since and what lies ahead. Their interviews have been edited and condensed.

title: They Call It Insane: Where Myanmar Sends Political Prisoners
description: The prison was already packed, its population more than double its 5,000-person capacity. Recent prisoners include two American journalists and an Australian economic adviser. Hundreds of pro-democracy protesters have also been crammed in, some with fresh gunshot wounds.

title: Plague of Mice in Australia Overruns Farms, Shops and Bedrooms
description: TOTTENHAM, Australia  The stench hits you first, pungent, musty and rotting. Then you hear them: a sound like ocean waves, or pouring rain hitting concrete. And the occasional squeak.

title: Where Do Ultramarathons Go From Here?
description: Ultrarunning got mainstream attention this week after a disastrous 62-mile mountain race in north-central China. Freezing rain, hail and high winds descended on the runners, ill prepared in shorts and short sleeves, leaving 21 people dead.

title: How to Take a Break
description: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you dont already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.

title: How Friends Helps People Around the World Learn English
description: True or false: In the television show Friends, Monica Geller was invited to Rachel Greens wedding.

title: 10 Y.A. Books to Add to Your Reading List This Summer
description: Ace of Spades, by Faridah Abike-Iyimide (Feiwel & Friends, June 1)

title: After Erdogan Angers a Loyal Province, His Opponents See an Opportunity
description: IKIZDERE, Turkey  Villagers in the pristine woodlands of Rize Province in northeastern Turkey have always had two natural advantages: a largely unspoiled landscape, rich in wildlife and trout-filled streams, and the protective influence of the regions most popular and powerful local citizen, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

title: At the Indianapolis 500, Scott Dixon Has the Pole Position. And More.
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Long before Scott Dixon became one of the most successful racecar drivers in history, winning six IndyCar Series championships and 51 races in a span of nearly two decades, he relied on his natural talent to get ahead.

title: Wimar Witoelar, Puckish Spokesman for Indonesian President, Dies at 75
description: Wimar Witoelar, a columnist, talk-show host, business consultant and political activist who served as media spokesman for the former Indonesian president Abdurrahman Wahid and brought a colorful presence to public life, died on May 19 at a hospital in South Jakarta. He was 75.

title: Before She Was C.E.O., She Cleaned Toilets. How Wonderful Is That?
description: When Land O Lakes redesigned its packaging last year to remove a decades-old illustration of a Native America woman, it seemed like just another dust-up in the culture wars. Liberal activists and politicians praised the company for abandoning stereotypical imagery. The conservative National Review ran a story titled Land OLakes Cancels Its Century-Old Native American Butter Maiden. Some customers boycotted the company for its virtue signaling.

title: Just in Time for Pool Season: A Chlorine Shortage
description: Stuck at home because of the coronavirus pandemic, people who found themselves sitting on savings from canceled vacations and other cutbacks built pools in record numbers last year to make quarantine more enjoyable.

title: Heres how holiday-weekend travel in the U.S. will be different from 2020.
description: Memorial Day weekend is underway in the United States, and things are decidedly different for travelers than they were a year ago.

title: Like a Dream: Latin Americans Head to U.S. for Covid Shots
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Florencia Gonzalez Alzaga, a photographer from Buenos Aires, hatched her plan to fly to the United States for a coronavirus vaccine after the subject came up in her Zoom book club.

title: Hong Kong exempts corporate executives from its strict quarantine rules, and other news from around the world.
description: Hong Kongs borders have been sealed for more than a year and its quarantine rules  which require compulsory hotel stays of up to three weeks  are among the strictest in the world.

title: Cookout Season Is Here!
description: The long weekend is upon us, and cookout planning is in full swing by the looks of this weeks most popular New York Times Cooking recipes. Whats on your menu? Maybe Kay Chuns Korean cheeseburgers will appear, alongside a bowl of Ali Slagles tahini-Parmesan pasta salad. Or Melissa Clarks grilled merguez and onions with mint-lemon couscous, supported by Lidey Heucks chickpea salad (above). No matter what you choose, one things for certain: Itll taste best outside, perhaps in a park, with a cold beer or lemonade in hand.

title: Working Less Is a Matter of Life and Death
description: Search online work too much and youll get screenfuls of information about the harmful medical, mental and social consequences of spending too much time on the job, going all the way back to that old saw first recorded in the 17th century, All work and no play makes Jack a dull boy.

title: Cops Dont Belong at Pride
description: My wife, Debbie, came out as a lesbian when she was 50 years old. Her first Pride parade in New York City was also the first time, she told me early in our courtship, that she was able to understand what it feels like to be proud. There is a picture of her on Christopher Street, beaming. She is wearing a T-shirt that says, Yep, Im Gay. Around her are hundreds of people from the L.G.B.T.Q. community, and allies, celebrating our right to be.

title: The Way of the Conscientious Objector
description: It was a book of Buddhist parables that put Michael Rasmussen over the edge. In March 2017, Mr. Rasmussen was living near a naval base in Japan, six years into training as a Marine pilot, reading and experimenting with meditation.

title: Ex-Commish With the Dish
description: Cops have never been so blue.

title: To Stem Suicide and Sexual Assault, the Air Force Dons Headsets
description: MCGUIRE AIR FORCE BASE, N.J.  The three airmen sat quietly adjusting their headsets, murmuring to their colleague, who was in distinct trouble. Everyone goes through rough patches sometimes, each said, a few moments apart, to the same despondent and mildly intoxicated man, whose wife recently left him and who seemed immersed in suicidal thoughts.

title: As G.O.P. Blocks Inquiry, Questions on Jan. 6 Attack May Go Unanswered
description: WASHINGTON  In blocking the formation of an independent commission to investigate the Jan. 6 Capitol riot, Republicans in Congress have all but closed off the possibility of a full and impartial accounting for one of the most serious assaults on American democracy in history, leaving unanswered critical questions with broad implications for politics, security and public trust.

title: Variety: Patchwork
description: PATCHWORK  Intertwining sets of entries, like Eric Berlin has done recently with new types of variety puzzles, is really so impressive; every time I solve one, I cant imagine how it gets constructed.
